Translated by William K. Marriott
INTRODUCTION

9.text:
Nicolo Machiavelli was born at Florence on
3rd May 1469. He was the second son of Bernardo

18.text:
di Nicolo Machiavelli, a lawyer of some repute,
and of Bartolommea di Stefano Nelli, his wife.

26.text:
Both parents were members of the old Florentine
nobility.

31.text:
His life falls naturally into three periods,
each of which singularly enough constitutes

37.text:
a distinct and important era in the history
of Florence. His youth was concurrent with

43.text:
the greatness of Florence as an Italian power
under the guidance of Lorenzo de' Medici,

49.text:
Il Magnifico. The downfall of the Medici in
Florence occurred in 1494, in which year Machiavelli

57.text:
entered the public service. During his official
career Florence was free under the government

62.text:
of a Republic, which lasted until 1512, when
the Medici returned to power, and Machiavelli

70.text:
lost his office. The Medici again ruled Florence
from 1512 until 1527, when they were once

77.text:
more driven out. This was the period of Machiavelli's
literary activity and increasing influence;

85.text:
but he died, within a few weeks of the expulsion
of the Medici, on 22nd June 1527, in his fifty-eighth

93.text:
year, without having regained office.
Heading

99.text:
YOUTH — Ages 1 to 25—1469-94
Although there is little recorded of the youth

109.text:
of Machiavelli, the Florence of those days
is so well known that the early environment

114.text:
of this representative citizen may be easily
imagined. Florence has been described as a

121.text:
city with two opposite currents of life, one
directed by the fervent and austere Savonarola,

128.text:
the other by the splendour-loving Lorenzo.
Savonarola's influence upon the young Machiavelli

135.text:
must have been slight, for although at one
time he wielded immense power over the fortunes

142.text:
of Florence, he only furnished Machiavelli
with a subject of a gibe in "The Prince,"

148.text:
where he is cited as an example of an unarmed
prophet who came to a bad end. Whereas the

154.text:
magnificence of the Medicean rule during the
life of Lorenzo appeared to have impressed

160.text:
Machiavelli strongly, for he frequently recurs
to it in his writings, and it is to Lorenzo's

167.text:
grandson that he dedicates "The Prince."
Machiavelli, in his "History of Florence,"

174.text:
gives us a picture of the young men among
whom his youth was passed. He writes: "They

180.text:
were freer than their forefathers in dress
and living, and spent more in other kinds

186.text:
of excesses, consuming their time and money
in idleness, gaming, and women; their chief

192.text:
aim was to appear well dressed and to speak
with wit and acuteness, whilst he who could

199.text:
wound others the most cleverly was thought
the wisest." In a letter to his son Guido,

206.text:
Machiavelli shows why youth should avail itself
of its opportunities for study, and leads

212.text:
us to infer that his own youth had been so
occupied. He writes: "I have received your

218.text:
letter, which has given me the greatest pleasure,
especially because you tell me you are quite

223.text:
restored in health, than which I could have
no better news; for if God grant life to you,

230.text:
and to me, I hope to make a good man of you
if you are willing to do your share." Then,

237.text:
writing of a new patron, he continues: "This
will turn out well for you, but it is necessary

242.text:
for you to study; since, then, you have no
longer the excuse of illness, take pains to

249.text:
study letters and music, for you see what
honour is done to me for the little skill

254.text:
I have. Therefore, my son, if you wish to
please me, and to bring success and honour

260.text:
to yourself, do right and study, because others
will help you if you help yourself."

266.text:
OFFICE — Ages 25-43—1494-1512
The second period of Machiavelli's life was

280.text:
spent in the service of the free Republic
of Florence, which flourished, as stated above,

286.text:
from the expulsion of the Medici in 1494 until
their return in 1512. After serving four years

294.text:
in one of the public offices he was appointed
Chancellor and Secretary to the Second Chancery,

301.text:
the Ten of Liberty and Peace. Here we are
on firm ground when dealing with the events

306.text:
of Machiavelli's life, for during this time
he took a leading part in the affairs of the

312.text:
Republic, and we have its decrees, records,
and dispatches to guide us, as well as his

318.text:
own writings. A mere recapitulation of a few
of his transactions with the statesmen and

324.text:
soldiers of his time gives a fair indication
of his activities, and supplies the sources

330.text:
from which he drew the experiences and characters
which illustrate "The Prince."

336.text:
His first mission was in 1499 to Catherina
Sforza, "my lady of Forli" of "The Prince,"

344.text:
from whose conduct and fate he drew the moral
that it is far better to earn the confidence

349.text:
of the people than to rely on fortresses.
This is a very noticeable principle in Machiavelli,

356.text:
and is urged by him in many ways as a matter
of vital importance to princes.

362.text:
In 1500 he was sent to France to obtain terms
from Louis XII for continuing the war against

369.text:
Pisa: this king it was who, in his conduct
of affairs in Italy, committed the five capital

377.text:
errors in statecraft summarized in "The Prince,"
and was consequently driven out. He, also,

385.text:
it was who made the dissolution of his marriage
a condition of support to Pope Alexander VI;

391.text:
which leads Machiavelli to refer those who
urge that such promises should be kept to

397.text:
what he has written concerning the faith of
princes.

401.text:
Machiavelli's public life was largely occupied
with events arising out of the ambitions of

407.text:
Pope Alexander VI and his son, Cesare Borgia,
the Duke Valentino, and these characters fill

414.text:
a large space of "The Prince." Machiavelli
never hesitates to cite the actions of the

421.text:
duke for the benefit of usurpers who wish
to keep the states they have seized; he can,

426.text:
indeed, find no precepts to offer so good
as the pattern of Cesare Borgia's conduct,

433.text:
insomuch that Cesare is acclaimed by some
critics as the "hero" of "The Prince." Yet

439.text:
in "The Prince" the duke is in point of fact
cited as a type of the man who rises on the

445.text:
fortune of others, and falls with them; who
takes every course that might be expected

450.text:
from a prudent man but the course which will
save him; who is prepared for all eventualities

457.text:
but the one which happens; and who, when all
his abilities fail to carry him through, exclaims

463.text:
that it was not his fault, but an extraordinary
and unforeseen fatality.

469.text:
On the death of Pius III, in 1503, Machiavelli
was sent to Rome to watch the election of

476.text:
his successor, and there he saw Cesare Borgia
cheated into allowing the choice of the College

482.text:
to fall on Giuliano delle Rovere (Julius II),
who was one of the cardinals that had most

489.text:
reason to fear the duke. Machiavelli, when
commenting on this election, says that he

495.text:
who thinks new favours will cause great personages
to forget old injuries deceives himself. Julius

503.text:
did not rest until he had ruined Cesare.
It was to Julius II that Machiavelli was sent

510.text:
in 1506, when that pontiff was commencing
his enterprise against Bologna; which he brought

517.text:
to a successful issue, as he did many of his
other adventures, owing chiefly to his impetuous

524.text:
character. It is in reference to Pope Julius
that Machiavelli moralizes on the resemblance

530.text:
between Fortune and women, and concludes that
it is the bold rather than the cautious man

536.text:
that will win and hold them both.
It is impossible to follow here the varying

543.text:
fortunes of the Italian states, which in 1507
were controlled by France, Spain, and Germany,

551.text:
with results that have lasted to our day;
we are concerned with those events, and with

557.text:
the three great actors in them, so far only
as they impinge on the personality of Machiavelli.

564.text:
He had several meetings with Louis XII of
France, and his estimate of that monarch's

569.text:
character has already been alluded to. Machiavelli
has painted Ferdinand of Aragon as the man

577.text:
who accomplished great things under the cloak
of religion, but who in reality had no mercy,

584.text:
faith, humanity, or integrity; and who, had
he allowed himself to be influenced by such

590.text:
motives, would have been ruined. The Emperor
Maximilian was one of the most interesting

597.text:
men of the age, and his character has been
drawn by many hands; but Machiavelli, who

603.text:
was an envoy at his court in 1507-8, reveals
the secret of his many failures when he describes

611.text:
him as a secretive man, without force of character—ignoring
the human agencies necessary to carry his

618.text:
schemes into effect, and never insisting on
the fulfilment of his wishes.

624.text:
The remaining years of Machiavelli's official
career were filled with events arising out

630.text:
of the League of Cambrai, made in 1508 between
the three great European powers already mentioned

637.text:
and the pope, with the object of crushing
the Venetian Republic. This result was attained

644.text:
in the battle of Vaila, when Venice lost in
one day all that she had won in eight hundred

650.text:
years. Florence had a difficult part to play
during these events, complicated as they were

657.text:
by the feud which broke out between the pope
and the French, because friendship with France

662.text:
had dictated the entire policy of the Republic.
When, in 1511, Julius II finally formed the

670.text:
Holy League against France, and with the assistance
of the Swiss drove the French out of Italy,

678.text:
Florence lay at the mercy of the Pope, and
had to submit to his terms, one of which was

683.text:
that the Medici should be restored. The return
of the Medici to Florence on 1st September

690.text:
1512, and the consequent fall of the Republic,
was the signal for the dismissal of Machiavelli

696.text:
and his friends, and thus put an end to his
public career, for, as we have seen, he died

703.text:
without regaining office.
LITERATURE AND DEATH — Ages 43-58—1512-27

715.text:
On the return of the Medici, Machiavelli,
who for a few weeks had vainly hoped to retain

721.text:
his office under the new masters of Florence,
was dismissed by decree dated 7th November

728.text:
1512. Shortly after this he was accused of
complicity in an abortive conspiracy against

735.text:
the Medici, imprisoned, and put to the question
by torture. The new Medicean pope, Leo X,

744.text:
procured his release, and he retired to his
small property at San Casciano, near Florence,

751.text:
where he devoted himself to literature. In
a letter to Francesco Vettori, dated 13th

758.text:
December 1513, he has left a very interesting
description of his life at this period, which

765.text:
elucidates his methods and his motives in
writing "The Prince." After describing his

771.text:
daily occupations with his family and neighbours,
he writes: "The evening being come, I return

779.text:
home and go to my study; at the entrance I
pull off my peasant-clothes, covered with

785.text:
dust and dirt, and put on my noble court dress,
and thus becomingly re-clothed I pass into

792.text:
the ancient courts of the men of old, where,
being lovingly received by them, I am fed

799.text:
with that food which is mine alone; where
I do not hesitate to speak with them, and

805.text:
to ask for the reason of their actions, and
they in their benignity answer me; and for

811.text:
four hours I feel no weariness, I forget every
trouble, poverty does not dismay, death does

818.text:
not terrify me; I am possessed entirely by
those great men. And because Dante says:

827.text:
Knowledge doth come of learning well retained,
Unfruitful else,

831.text:
I have noted down what I have gained from
their conversation, and have composed a small

837.text:
work on 'Principalities,' where I pour myself
out as fully as I can in meditation on the

844.text:
subject, discussing what a principality is,
what kinds there are, how they can be acquired,

851.text:
how they can be kept, why they are lost: and
if any of my fancies ever pleased you, this

857.text:
ought not to displease you: and to a prince,
especially to a new one, it should be welcome:

865.text:
therefore I dedicate it to his Magnificence
Giuliano. Filippo Casavecchio has seen it;

872.text:
he will be able to tell you what is in it,
and of the discourses I have had with him;

878.text:
nevertheless, I am still enriching and polishing
it."

882.text:
The "little book" suffered many vicissitudes
before attaining the form in which it has

888.text:
reached us. Various mental influences were
at work during its composition; its title

894.text:
and patron were changed; and for some unknown
reason it was finally dedicated to Lorenzo

900.text:
de' Medici. Although Machiavelli discussed
with Casavecchio whether it should be sent

906.text:
or presented in person to the patron, there
is no evidence that Lorenzo ever received

911.text:
or even read it: he certainly never gave Machiavelli
any employment. Although it was plagiarized

918.text:
during Machiavelli's lifetime, "The Prince"
was never published by him, and its text is

924.text:
still disputable.
Machiavelli concludes his letter to Vettori

930.text:
thus: "And as to this little thing [his book],
when it has been read it will be seen that

936.text:
during the fifteen years I have given to the
study of statecraft I have neither slept nor

942.text:
idled; and men ought ever to desire to be
served by one who has reaped experience at

949.text:
the expense of others. And of my loyalty none
could doubt, because having always kept faith

956.text:
I could not now learn how to break it; for
he who has been faithful and honest, as I

962.text:
have, cannot change his nature; and my poverty
is a witness to my honesty."

969.text:
Before Machiavelli had got "The Prince" off
his hands he commenced his "Discourse on the

974.text:
First Decade of Titus Livius," which should
be read concurrently with "The Prince." These

980.text:
and several minor works occupied him until
the year 1518, when he accepted a small commission

987.text:
to look after the affairs of some Florentine
merchants at Genoa. In 1519 the Medicean rulers

996.text:
of Florence granted a few political concessions
to her citizens, and Machiavelli with others

1003.text:
was consulted upon a new constitution under
which the Great Council was to be restored;

1009.text:
but on one pretext or another it was not promulgated.
In 1520 the Florentine merchants again had

1018.text:
recourse to Machiavelli to settle their difficulties
with Lucca, but this year was chiefly remarkable

1024.text:
for his re-entry into Florentine literary
society, where he was much sought after, and

1031.text:
also for the production of his "Art of War."
It was in the same year that he received a

1037.text:
commission at the instance of Cardinal de'
Medici to write the "History of Florence,"

1042.text:
a task which occupied him until 1525. His
return to popular favour may have determined

1050.text:
the Medici to give him this employment, for
an old writer observes that "an able statesman

1056.text:
out of work, like a huge whale, will endeavour
to overturn the ship unless he has an empty

1062.text:
cask to play with."
When the "History of Florence" was finished,

1067.text:
Machiavelli took it to Rome for presentation
to his patron, Giuliano de' Medici, who had

1074.text:
in the meanwhile become pope under the title
of Clement VII. It is somewhat remarkable

1080.text:
that, as, in 1513, Machiavelli had written
"The Prince" for the instruction of the Medici

1087.text:
after they had just regained power in Florence,
so, in 1525, he dedicated the "History of

1095.text:
Florence" to the head of the family when its
ruin was now at hand. In that year the battle

1101.text:
of Pavia destroyed the French rule in Italy,
and left Francis I a prisoner in the hands

1108.text:
of his great rival, Charles V. This was followed
by the sack of Rome, upon the news of which

1115.text:
the popular party at Florence threw off the
yoke of the Medici, who were once more banished.

1122.text:
Machiavelli was absent from Florence at this
time, but hastened his return, hoping to secure

1128.text:
his former office of secretary to the "Ten
of Liberty and Peace." Unhappily he was taken

1135.text:
ill soon after he reached Florence, where
he died on 22nd June 1527.

1144.text:
THE MAN AND HIS WORKS
No one can say where the bones of Machiavelli

1149.text:
rest, but modern Florence has decreed him
a stately cenotaph in Santa Croce, by the

1155.text:
side of her most famous sons; recognizing
that, whatever other nations may have found

1161.text:
in his works, Italy found in them the idea
of her unity and the germs of her renaissance

1168.text:
among the nations of Europe. Whilst it is
idle to protest against the world-wide and

1174.text:
evil signification of his name, it may be
pointed out that the harsh construction of

1179.text:
his doctrine which this sinister reputation
implies was unknown to his own day, and that

1186.text:
the researches of recent times have enabled
us to interpret him more reasonably. It is

1192.text:
due to these inquiries that the shape of an
"unholy necromancer," which so long haunted

1199.text:
men's vision, has begun to fade.
Machiavelli was undoubtedly a man of great

1206.text:
observation, acuteness, and industry; noting
with appreciative eye whatever passed before

1214.text:
him, and with his supreme literary gift turning
it to account in his enforced retirement from

1221.text:
affairs. He does not present himself, nor
is he depicted by his contemporaries, as a

1227.text:
type of that rare combination, the successful
statesman and author, for he appears to have

1233.text:
been only moderately prosperous in his several
embassies and political employments. He was

1240.text:
misled by Catherina Sforza, ignored by Louis
XII, overawed by Cesare Borgia; several of

1248.text:
his embassies were quite barren of results;
his attempts to fortify Florence failed, and

1254.text:
the soldiery that he raised astonished everybody
by their cowardice. In the conduct of his

1261.text:
own affairs he was timid and time-serving;
he dared not appear by the side of Soderini,

1267.text:
to whom he owed so much, for fear of compromising
himself; his connection with the Medici was

1274.text:
open to suspicion, and Giuliano appears to
have recognized his real forte when he set

1280.text:
him to write the "History of Florence," rather
than employ him in the state. And it is on

1287.text:
the literary side of his character, and there
alone, that we find no weakness and no failure.

1296.text:
Although the light of almost four centuries
has been focused on "The Prince," its problems

1301.text:
are still debatable and interesting, because
they are the eternal problems between the

1307.text:
ruled and their rulers. Such as they are,
its ethics are those of Machiavelli's contemporaries;

1315.text:
yet they cannot be said to be out of date
so long as the governments of Europe rely

1319.text:
on material rather than on moral forces. Its
historical incidents and personages become

1327.text:
interesting by reason of the uses which Machiavelli
makes of them to illustrate his theories of

1333.text:
government and conduct.
Leaving out of consideration those maxims

1338.text:
of state which still furnish some European
and eastern statesmen with principles of action,

1344.text:
"The Prince" is bestrewn with truths that
can be proved at every turn. Men are still

1351.text:
the dupes of their simplicity and greed, as
they were in the days of Alexander VI. The

1357.text:
cloak of religion still conceals the vices
which Machiavelli laid bare in the character

1364.text:
of Ferdinand of Aragon. Men will not look
at things as they really are, but as they

1369.text:
wish them to be—and are ruined. In politics
there are no perfectly safe courses; prudence

1377.text:
consists in choosing the least dangerous ones.
Then—to pass to a higher plane—Machiavelli

1384.text:
reiterates that, although crimes may win an
empire, they do not win glory. Necessary wars

1392.text:
are just wars, and the arms of a nation are
hallowed when it has no other resource but

1399.text:
to fight.
It is the cry of a far later day than Machiavelli's

1405.text:
that government should be elevated into a
living moral force, capable of inspiring the

1411.text:
people with a just recognition of the fundamental
principles of society; to this "high argument"

1418.text:
"The Prince" contributes but little. Machiavelli
always refused to write either of men or of

1425.text:
governments otherwise than as he found them,
and he writes with such skill and insight

1431.text:
that his work is of abiding value. But what
invests "The Prince" with more than a merely

1436.text:
artistic or historical interest is the incontrovertible
truth that it deals with the great principles

1444.text:
which still guide nations and rulers in their
relationship with each other and their neighbours.

1452.text:
In translating "The Prince" my aim has been
to achieve at all costs an exact literal rendering

1458.text:
of the original, rather than a fluent paraphrase
adapted to the modern notions of style and

1465.text:
expression. Machiavelli was no facile phrasemonger;
the conditions under which he wrote obliged

1472.text:
him to weigh every word; his themes were lofty,
his substance grave, his manner nobly plain

1480.text:
and serious. "Quis eo fuit unquam in partiundis
rebus, in definiendis, in explanandis pressior?"

1491.text:
In "The Prince," it may be truly said, there
is reason assignable, not only for every word,

1497.text:
but for the position of every word. To an
Englishman of Shakespeare's time the translation

1503.text:
of such a treatise was in some ways a comparatively
easy task, for in those times the genius of

1511.text:
the English more nearly resembled that of
the Italian language; to the Englishman of

1516.text:
to-day it is not so simple. To take a single
example: the word "intrattenere," employed

1523.text:
by Machiavelli to indicate the policy adopted
by the Roman Senate towards the weaker states

1529.text:
of Greece, would by an Elizabethan be correctly
rendered "entertain," and every contemporary

1536.text:
reader would understand what was meant by
saying that "Rome entertained the Aetolians

1542.text:
and the Achaeans without augmenting their
power." But to-day such a phrase would seem

1548.text:
obsolete and ambiguous, if not unmeaning:
we are compelled to say that "Rome maintained

1555.text:
friendly relations with the Aetolians," etc.,
using four words to do the work of one. I

1563.text:
have tried to preserve the pithy brevity of
the Italian so far as was consistent with

1569.text:
an absolute fidelity to the sense. If the
result be an occasional asperity I can only

1575.text:
hope that the reader, in his eagerness to
reach the author's meaning, may overlook the

1580.text:
roughness of the road that leads him to it.
The following is a list of the works of Machiavelli:

1593.text:
Principal works. Discorso sopra le cose di
Pisa, 1499; Del modo di trattare i popoli

1605.text:
della Valdichiana ribellati, 1502; Del modo
tenuto dal duca Valentino nell' ammazzare

1613.text:
Vitellozzo Vitelli, Oliverotto da Fermo, etc.,
1502; Discorso sopra la provisione del danaro,

1616.text:
1502; Decennale primo (poem in terza rima),
1506; Ritratti delle cose dell' Alemagna,

1620.text:
1508-12; Decennale secondo, 1509; Ritratti
delle cose di Francia, 1510; Discorsi sopra

1623.text:
la prima deca di T. Livio, 3 vols., 1512-17;
Il Principe, 1513; Andria, comedy translated

1629.text:
from Terence, 1513 (?); Mandragola, prose
comedy in five acts, with prologue in verse,

1635.text:
1513; Della lingua (dialogue), 1514; Clizia,
comedy in prose, 1515 (?); Belfagor arcidiavolo

1640.text:
(novel), 1515; Asino d'oro (poem in terza
rima), 1517; Dell' arte della guerra, 1519-20;

1646.text:
Discorso sopra il riformare lo stato di Firenze,
1520; Sommario delle cose della citta di Lucca,

1660.text:
1520; Vita di Castruccio Castracani da Lucca,
1520; Istorie fiorentine, 8 books, 1521-5;

1723.text:
Frammenti storici, 1525.
Other poems include Sonetti, Canzoni, Ottave,

1740.text:
and Canti carnascialeschi.
Editions. Aldo, Venice, 1546; della Tertina,

1751.text:
1550; Cambiagi, Florence, 6 vols., 1782-5;
dei Classici, Milan, 10 1813; Silvestri, 9

1764.text:
vols., 1820-2; Passerini, Fanfani, Milanesi,
6 vols. only published, 1873-7.

1775.text:
Minor works. Ed. F. L. Polidori, 1852; Lettere
familiari, ed. E. Alvisi, 1883, 2 editions,

1786.text:
one with excisions; Credited Writings, ed.
G. Canestrini, 1857; Letters to F. Vettori,

1795.text:
see A. Ridolfi, Pensieri intorno allo scopo
di N. Machiavelli nel libro Il Principe, etc.;

1805.text:
D. Ferrara, The Private Correspondence of
Nicolo Machiavelli, 1929.

1814.text:
DEDICATION
To the Magnificent Lorenzo Di Piero De' Medici:

1820.text:
Those who strive to obtain the good graces
of a prince are

1824.text:
accustomed to come before him with such things
as they hold most

1827.text:
precious, or in which they see him take most
delight; whence one

1832.text:
often sees horses, arms, cloth of gold, precious
stones, and

1837.text:
similar ornaments presented to princes, worthy
of their greatness.

1843.text:
Desiring therefore to present myself to your
Magnificence with

1847.text:
some testimony of my devotion towards you,
I have not found among

1851.text:
my possessions anything which I hold more
dear than, or value so

1856.text:
much as, the knowledge of the actions of great
men, acquired by

1861.text:
long experience in contemporary affairs, and
a continual study of

1867.text:
antiquity; which, having reflected upon it
with great and

1870.text:
prolonged diligence, I now send, digested
into a little volume, to

1876.text:
your Magnificence.
And although I may consider this work unworthy

1881.text:
of your
countenance, nevertheless I trust much to

1885.text:
your benignity that it
may be acceptable, seeing that it is not possible

1890.text:
for me to make a
better gift than to offer you the opportunity

1893.text:
of understanding in
the shortest time all that I have learnt in

1897.text:
so many years, and
with so many troubles and dangers; which work

1903.text:
I have not
embellished with swelling or magnificent words,

1907.text:
nor stuffed with
rounded periods, nor with any extrinsic allurements

1912.text:
or adornments
whatever, with which so many are accustomed

1916.text:
to embellish their
works; for I have wished either that no honour

1921.text:
should be given it,
or else that the truth of the matter and the

1925.text:
weightiness of the
theme shall make it acceptable.

1929.text:
Nor do I hold with those who regard it as
a presumption if a man

1933.text:
of low and humble condition dare to discuss
and settle the

1938.text:
concerns of princes; because, just as those
who draw landscapes

1943.text:
place themselves below in the plain to contemplate
the nature of

1947.text:
the mountains and of lofty places, and in
order to contemplate the

1951.text:
plains place themselves upon high mountains,
even so to understand

1957.text:
the nature of the people it needs to be a
prince, and to

1960.text:
understand that of princes it needs to be
of the people.

1965.text:
Take then, your Magnificence, this little
gift in the spirit in

1969.text:
which I send it; wherein, if it be diligently
read and considered

1974.text:
by you, you will learn my extreme desire that
you should attain

1979.text:
that greatness which fortune and your other
attributes promise.

1985.text:
And if your Magnificence from the summit of
your greatness will

1988.text:
sometimes turn your eyes to these lower regions,
you will see how

1993.text:
unmeritedly I suffer a great and continued
malignity of fortune.

2001.text:
End of front matter.
CHAPTER I — HOW MANY KINDS OF PRINCIPALITIES

2008.text:
THERE ARE, AND BY WHAT MEANS THEY ARE ACQUIRED
All states, all powers, that have held and

2014.text:
hold rule over men have been and are either
republics or principalities.

2022.text:
Principalities are either hereditary, in which
the family has been long established; or they

2026.text:
are new.
The new are either entirely new, as was Milan

2030.text:
to Francesco Sforza, or they are, as it were,
members annexed to the hereditary state of

2037.text:
the prince who has acquired them, as was the
kingdom of Naples to that of the King of Spain.

2043.text:
Such dominions thus acquired are either accustomed
to live under a prince, or to live in freedom;

2050.text:
and are acquired either by the arms of the
prince himself, or of others, or else by fortune

2056.text:
or by ability.
End of Chapter I

2060.text:
CHAPTER II — CONCERNING HEREDITARY PRINCIPALITIES
I will leave out all discussion on republics,

2066.text:
inasmuch as in another place I have written
of them at length, and will address myself

2070.text:
only to principalities. In doing so I will
keep to the order indicated above, and discuss

2077.text:
how such principalities are to be ruled and
preserved.

2082.text:
I say at once there are fewer difficulties
in holding hereditary states, and those long

2087.text:
accustomed to the family of their prince,
than new ones; for it is sufficient only not

2093.text:
to transgress the customs of his ancestors,
and to deal prudently with circumstances as

2099.text:
they arise, for a prince of average powers
to maintain himself in his state, unless he

2104.text:
be deprived of it by some extraordinary and
excessive force; and if he should be so deprived

2110.text:
of it, whenever anything sinister happens
to the usurper, he will regain it.

2116.text:
We have in Italy, for example, the Duke of
Ferrara, who could not have withstood the

2121.text:
attacks of the Venetians in '84, nor those
of Pope Julius in '10, unless he had been

2127.text:
long established in his dominions. For the
hereditary prince has less cause and less

2132.text:
necessity to offend; hence it happens that
he will be more loved; and unless extraordinary

2139.text:
vices cause him to be hated, it is reasonable
to expect that his subjects will be naturally

2145.text:
well disposed towards him; and in the antiquity
and duration of his rule the memories and

2151.text:
motives that make for change are lost, for
one change always leaves the toothing for

2161.text:
CHAPTER III — CONCERNING MIXED PRINCIPALITIES
But the difficulties occur in a new principality.

2167.text:
And firstly, if it be not entirely new, but
is, as it were, a member of a state which,

2174.text:
taken collectively, may be called composite,
the changes arise chiefly from an inherent

2180.text:
difficulty which there is in all new principalities;
for men change their rulers willingly, hoping

2186.text:
to better themselves, and this hope induces
them to take up arms against him who rules:

2193.text:
wherein they are deceived, because they afterwards
find by experience they have gone from bad

2199.text:
to worse. This follows also on another natural
and common necessity, which always causes

2206.text:
a new prince to burden those who have submitted
to him with his soldiery and with infinite

2212.text:
other hardships which he must put upon his
new acquisition.

2217.text:
In this way you have enemies in all those
whom you have injured in seizing that principality,

2223.text:
and you are not able to keep those friends
who put you there because of your not being

2227.text:
able to satisfy them in the way they expected,
and you cannot take strong measures against

2233.text:
them, feeling bound to them. For, although
one may be very strong in armed forces, yet

2240.text:
in entering a province one has always need
of the goodwill of the natives.

2246.text:
For these reasons Louis the Twelfth, King
of France, quickly occupied Milan, and as

2251.text:
quickly lost it; and to turn him out the first
time it only needed Lodovico's own forces;

2259.text:
because those who had opened the gates to
him, finding themselves deceived in their

2263.text:
hopes of future benefit, would not endure
the ill-treatment of the new prince. It is

2269.text:
very true that, after acquiring rebellious
provinces a second time, they are not so lightly

2275.text:
lost afterwards, because the prince, with
little reluctance, takes the opportunity of

2280.text:
the rebellion to punish the delinquents, to
clear out the suspects, and to strengthen

2286.text:
himself in the weakest places. Thus to cause
France to lose Milan the first time it was

2293.text:
enough for the Duke Lodovico [Footnote: Duke
Lodovico was Lodovico Moro, a son of Francesco

2301.text:
Sforza, who married Beatrice d'Este. He ruled
over Milan from 1494 to 1500, and died in

2309.text:
1510.]
Thus to cause France to lose Milan the first

2313.text:
time it was enough for the Duke Lodovico to
raise insurrections on the borders; but to

2320.text:
cause him to lose it a second time it was
necessary to bring the whole world against

2325.text:
him, and that his armies should be defeated
and driven out of Italy; which followed from

2331.text:
the causes above mentioned.
Nevertheless Milan was taken from France both

2337.text:
the first and the second time. The general
reasons for the first have been discussed;

2343.text:
it remains to name those for the second, and
to see what resources he had, and what any

2348.text:
one in his situation would have had for maintaining
himself more securely in his acquisition than

2354.text:
did the King of France.
Now I say that those dominions which, when

2360.text:
acquired, are added to an ancient state by
him who acquires them, are either of the same

2365.text:
country and language, or they are not. When
they are, it is easier to hold them, especially

2371.text:
when they have not been accustomed to self-government;
and to hold them securely it is enough to

2376.text:
have destroyed the family of the prince who
was ruling them; because the two peoples,

2382.text:
preserving in other things the old conditions,
and not being unlike in customs, will live

2387.text:
quietly together, as one has seen in Brittany,
Burgundy, Gascony, and Normandy, which have

2393.text:
been bound to France for so long a time: and,
although there may be some difference in language,

2400.text:
nevertheless the customs are alike, and the
people will easily be able to get on amongst

2404.text:
themselves. He who has annexed them, if he
wishes to hold them, has only to bear in mind

2410.text:
two considerations: the one, that the family
of their former lord is extinguished; the

2416.text:
other, that neither their laws nor their taxes
are altered, so that in a very short time

2422.text:
they will become entirely one body with the
old principality.

2427.text:
But when states are acquired in a country
differing in language, customs, or laws, there

2432.text:
are difficulties, and good fortune and great
energy are needed to hold them, and one of

2437.text:
the greatest and most real helps would be
that he who has acquired them should go and

2442.text:
reside there. This would make his position
more secure and durable, as it has made that

2448.text:
of the Turk in Greece, who, notwithstanding
all the other measures taken by him for holding

2454.text:
that state, if he had not settled there, would
not have been able to keep it. Because, if

2460.text:
one is on the spot, disorders are seen as
they spring up, and one can quickly remedy

2465.text:
them; but if one is not at hand, they are
heard of only when they are great, and then

2470.text:
one can no longer remedy them. Besides this,
the country is not pillaged by your officials;

2476.text:
the subjects are satisfied by prompt recourse
to the prince; thus, wishing to be good, they

2483.text:
have more cause to love him, and wishing to
be otherwise, to fear him. He who would attack

2489.text:
that state from the outside must have the
utmost caution; as long as the prince resides

2494.text:
there it can only be wrested from him with
the greatest difficulty.

2499.text:
The other and better course is to send colonies
to one or two places, which may be as keys

2505.text:
to that state, for it is necessary either
to do this or else to keep there a great number

2511.text:
of cavalry and infantry. A prince does not
spend much on colonies, for with little or

2517.text:
no expense he can send them out and keep them
there, and he offends a minority only of the

2523.text:
citizens from whom he takes lands and houses
to give them to the new inhabitants; and those

2529.text:
whom he offends, remaining poor and scattered,
are never able to injure him; whilst the rest

2536.text:
being uninjured are easily kept quiet, and
at the same time are anxious not to err for

2542.text:
fear it should happen to them as it has to
those who have been despoiled. In conclusion,

2547.text:
I say that these colonies are not costly,
they are more faithful, they injure less,

2553.text:
and the injured, as has been said, being poor
and scattered, cannot hurt. Upon this, one

2559.text:
has to remark that men ought either to be
well treated or crushed, because they can

2565.text:
avenge themselves of lighter injuries, of
more serious ones they cannot; therefore the

2571.text:
injury that is to be done to a man ought to
be of such a kind that one does not stand

2576.text:
in fear of revenge.
But in maintaining armed men there in place

2582.text:
of colonies one spends much more, having to
consume on the garrison all the income from

2588.text:
the state, so that the acquisition turns into
a loss, and many more are exasperated, because

2594.text:
the whole state is injured; through the shifting
of the garrison up and down all become acquainted

2600.text:
with hardship, and all become hostile, and
they are enemies who, whilst beaten on their

2606.text:
own ground, are yet able to do hurt. For every
reason, therefore, such guards are as useless

2613.text:
as a colony is useful.
Again, the prince who holds a country differing

2619.text:
in the above respects ought to make himself
the head and defender of his less powerful

2626.text:
neighbours, and to weaken the more powerful
amongst them, taking care that no foreigner

2630.text:
as powerful as himself shall, by any accident,
get a footing there; for it will always happen

2637.text:
that such a one will be introduced by those
who are discontented, either through excess

2642.text:
of ambition or through fear, as one has seen
already. The Romans were brought into Greece

2648.text:
by the Aetolians; and in every other country
where they obtained a footing they were brought

2653.text:
in by the inhabitants. And the usual course
of affairs is that, as soon as a powerful

2659.text:
foreigner enters a country, all the subject
states are drawn to him, moved by the hatred

2665.text:
which they feel against the ruling power.
So that in respect to those subject states

2670.text:
he has not to take any trouble to gain them
over to himself, for the whole of them quickly

2676.text:
rally to the state which he has acquired there.
He has only to take care that they do not

2681.text:
get hold of too much power and too much authority,
and then with his own forces, and with their

2688.text:
goodwill, he can easily keep down the more
powerful of them, so as to remain entirely

2693.text:
master in the country. And he who does not
properly manage this business will soon lose

2699.text:
what he has acquired, and whilst he does hold
it he will have endless difficulties and troubles.

2706.text:
The Romans, in the countries which they annexed,
observed closely these measures; they sent

2711.text:
colonies and maintained friendly relations
with the minor powers, without increasing

2722.text:
their strength; they kept down the greater,
and did not allow any strong foreign powers

2727.text:
to gain authority. Greece appears to me sufficient
for an example. The Achaeans and Aetolians

2734.text:
were kept friendly by them, the kingdom of
Macedonia was humbled, Antiochus was driven

2740.text:
out; yet the merits of the Achaeans and Aetolians
never secured for them permission to increase

2747.text:
their power, nor did the persuasions of Philip
ever induce the Romans to be his friends without

2753.text:
first humbling him, nor did the influence
of Antiochus make them agree that he should

2758.text:
retain any lordship over the country. Because
the Romans did in these instances what all

2765.text:
prudent princes ought to do, who have to regard
not only present troubles, but also future

2771.text:
ones, for which they must prepare with every
energy, because, when foreseen, it is easy

2776.text:
to remedy them; but if you wait until they
approach, the medicine is no longer in time

2782.text:
because the malady has become incurable; for
it happens in this, as the physicians say

2787.text:
it happens in hectic fever, that in the beginning
of the malady it is easy to cure but difficult

2793.text:
to detect, but in the course of time, not
having been either detected or treated in

2799.text:
the beginning, it becomes easy to detect but
difficult to cure. This it happens in affairs

2805.text:
of state, for when the evils that arise have
been foreseen (which it is only given to a

2810.text:
wise man to see), they can be quickly redressed,
but when, through not having been foreseen,

2817.text:
they have been permitted to grow in a way
that every one can see them, there is no longer

2822.text:
a remedy. Therefore, the Romans, foreseeing
troubles, dealt with them at once, and, even

2829.text:
to avoid a war, would not let them come to
a head, for they knew that war is not to be

2835.text:
avoided, but is only to be put off to the
advantage of others; moreover they wished

2840.text:
to fight with Philip and Antiochus in Greece
so as not to have to do it in Italy; they

2846.text:
could have avoided both, but this they did
not wish; nor did that ever please them which

2851.text:
is for ever in the mouths of the wise ones
of our time:—Let us enjoy the benefits of

2857.text:
the time—but rather the benefits of their
own valour and prudence, for time drives everything

2863.text:
before it, and is able to bring with it good
as well as evil, and evil as well as good.

2870.text:
But let us turn to France and inquire whether
she has done any of the things mentioned.

2875.text:
I will speak of Louis [Footnote: Louis XII,
King of France, "The Father of the People,"

2881.text:
born 1462, died 1515.] (and not of Charles)
[Footnote: Charles VIII, King of France, born

2890.text:
1470, died 1498] I will speak of Louis and
not of Charles as the one whose conduct is

2897.text:
the better to be observed, he having held
possession of Italy for the longest period;

2902.text:
and you will see that he has done the opposite
to those things which ought to be done to

2907.text:
retain a state composed of divers elements.
King Louis was brought into Italy by the ambition

2914.text:
of the Venetians, who desired to obtain half
the state of Lombardy by his intervention.

2920.text:
I will not blame the course taken by the king,
because, wishing to get a foothold in Italy,

2926.text:
and having no friends there—seeing rather
that every door was shut to him owing to the

2931.text:
conduct of Charles—he was forced to accept
those friendships which he could get, and

2937.text:
he would have succeeded very quickly in his
design if in other matters he had not made

2942.text:
some mistakes. The king, however, having acquired
Lombardy, regained at once the authority which

2948.text:
Charles had lost: Genoa yielded; the Florentines
became his friends; the Marquess of Mantua,

2955.text:
the Duke of Ferrara, the Bentivogli, my lady
of Forli, the Lords of Faenza, of Pesaro,

2963.text:
of Rimini, of Camerino, of Piombino, the Lucchese,
the Pisans, the Sienese—everybody made advances

2969.text:
to him to become his friend. Then could the
Venetians realize the rashness of the course

2975.text:
taken by them, which, in order that they might
secure two towns in Lombardy, had made the

2981.text:
king master of two-thirds of Italy.
Let any one now consider with what little

2987.text:
difficulty the king could have maintained
his position in Italy had he observed the

2991.text:
rules above laid down, and kept all his friends
secure and protected; for although they were

2998.text:
numerous they were both weak and timid, some
afraid of the Church, some of the Venetians,

3004.text:
and thus they would always have been forced
to stand in with him, and by their means he

3009.text:
could easily have made himself secure against
those who remained powerful. But he was no

3014.text:
sooner in Milan than he did the contrary by
assisting Pope Alexander to occupy the Romagna.

3022.text:
It never occurred to him that by this action
he was weakening himself, depriving himself

3027.text:
of friends and of those who had thrown themselves
into his lap, whilst he aggrandized the Church

3033.text:
by adding much temporal power to the spiritual,
thus giving it greater authority. And having

3040.text:
committed this prime error, he was obliged
to follow it up, so much so that, to put an

3046.text:
end to the ambition of Alexander, and to prevent
his becoming the master of Tuscany, he was

3051.text:
himself forced to come into Italy.
And as if it were not enough to have aggrandized

3058.text:
the Church, and deprived himself of friends,
he, wishing to have the kingdom of Naples,

3064.text:
divides it with the King of Spain, and where
he was the prime arbiter in Italy he takes

3069.text:
an associate, so that the ambitious of that
country and the malcontents of his own should

3076.text:
have somewhere to shelter; and whereas he
could have left in the kingdom his own pensioner

3081.text:
as king, he drove him out, to put one there
who was able to drive him, Louis, out in turn.

3089.text:
The wish to acquire is in truth very natural
and common, and men always do so when they

3095.text:
can, and for this they will be praised not
blamed; but when they cannot do so, yet wish

3100.text:
to do so by any means, then there is folly
and blame. Therefore, if France could have

3106.text:
attacked Naples with her own forces she ought
to have done so; if she could not, then she

3112.text:
ought not to have divided it. And if the partition
which she made with the Venetians in Lombardy

3117.text:
was justified by the excuse that by it she
got a foothold in Italy, this other partition

3123.text:
merited blame, for it had not the excuse of
that necessity.

3129.text:
Therefore Louis made these five errors: he
destroyed the minor powers, he increased the

3135.text:
strength of one of the greater powers in Italy,
he brought in a foreign power, he did not

3140.text:
settle in the country, he did not send colonies.
Which errors, had he lived, were not enough

3147.text:
to injure him had he not made a sixth by taking
away their dominions from the Venetians; because,

3154.text:
had he not aggrandized the Church, nor brought
Spain into Italy, it would have been very

3159.text:
reasonable and necessary to humble them; but
having first taken these steps, he ought never

3165.text:
to have consented to their ruin, for they,
being powerful, would always have kept off

3170.text:
others from designs on Lombardy, to which
the Venetians would never have consented except

3176.text:
to become masters themselves there; also because
the others would not wish to take Lombardy

3182.text:
from France in order to give it to the Venetians,
and to run counter to both they would not

3187.text:
have had the courage.
And if any one should say: "King Louis yielded

3192.text:
the Romagna to Alexander and the kingdom to
Spain to avoid war," I answer for the reasons

3199.text:
given above that a blunder ought never to
be perpetrated to avoid war, because it is

3204.text:
not to be avoided, but is only deferred to
your disadvantage. And if another should allege

3211.text:
the pledge which the king had given to the
Pope that he would assist him in the enterprise,

3216.text:
in exchange for the dissolution of his marriage
and for the cap to Rouen, to that I reply

3221.text:
what I shall write later on concerning the
faith of princes, and how it ought to be kept.

3227.text:
[Footnote: Louis XII divorced his wife, Jeanne,
daughter of Louis XI, and married in 1499

3235.text:
Anne of Brittany, widow of Charles VIII, in
order to retain the Duchy of Brittany for

3241.text:
the crown.]
[Footnote: The Archbishop of Rouen. He was

3245.text:
Georges d'Amboise, created a cardinal by Alexander
VI. Born 1460, died 1510.]

3255.text:
Thus King Louis lost Lombardy by not having
followed any of the conditions observed by

3260.text:
those who have taken possession of countries
and wished to retain them. Nor is there any

3265.text:
miracle in this, but much that is reasonable
and quite natural. And on these matters I

3271.text:
spoke at Nantes with Rouen, when Valentino,
as Cesare Borgia, the son of Pope Alexander,

3278.text:
was usually called, occupied the Romagna,
and on Cardinal Rouen observing to me that

3284.text:
the Italians did not understand war, I replied
to him that the French did not understand

3290.text:
statecraft, meaning that otherwise they would
not have allowed the Church to reach such

3295.text:
greatness. And in fact is has been seen that
the greatness of the Church and of Spain in

3300.text:
Italy has been caused by France, and her ruin
may be attributed to them. From this a general

3308.text:
rule is drawn which never or rarely fails:
that he who is the cause of another becoming

3314.text:
powerful is ruined; because that predominancy
has been brought about either by astuteness

3320.text:
or else by force, and both are distrusted
by him who has been raised to power.

3329.text:
End of Chapter III
CHAPTER IV — WHY THE KINGDOM OF DARIUS,

3336.text:
CONQUERED BY ALEXANDER, DID NOT REBEL AGAINST
THE SUCCESSORS OF ALEXANDER AT HIS DEATH

3343.text:
Considering the difficulties which men have
had to hold to a newly acquired state, some

3348.text:
might wonder how, seeing that Alexander the
Great became the master of Asia in a few years,

3354.text:
and died whilst it was scarcely settled (whence
it might appear reasonable that the whole

3359.text:
empire would have rebelled), nevertheless
his successors maintained themselves, and

3365.text:
had to meet no other difficulty than that
which arose among themselves from their own

3370.text:
ambitions.
I answer that the principalities of which

3374.text:
one has record are found to be governed in
two different ways; either by a prince, with

3380.text:
a body of servants, who assist him to govern
the kingdom as ministers by his favour and

3385.text:
permission; or by a prince and barons, who
hold that dignity by antiquity of blood and

3391.text:
not by the grace of the prince. Such barons
have states and their own subjects, who recognize

3398.text:
them as lords and hold them in natural affection.
Those states that are governed by a prince

3405.text:
and his servants hold their prince in more
consideration, because in all the country

3410.text:
there is no one who is recognized as superior
to him, and if they yield obedience to another

3417.text:
they do it as to a minister and official,
and they do not bear him any particular affection.

3423.text:
The examples of these two governments in our
time are the Turk and the King of France.

3429.text:
The entire monarchy of the Turk is governed
by one lord, the others are his servants;

3435.text:
and, dividing his kingdom into sanjaks, he
sends there different administrators, and

3441.text:
shifts and changes them as he chooses. But
the King of France is placed in the midst

3446.text:
of an ancient body of lords, acknowledged
by their own subjects, and beloved by them;

3453.text:
they have their own prerogatives, nor can
the king take these away except at his peril.

3458.text:
Therefore, he who considers both of these
states will recognize great difficulties in

3463.text:
seizing the state of the Turk, but, once it
is conquered, great ease in holding it. The

3471.text:
causes of the difficulties in seizing the
kingdom of the Turk are that the usurper cannot

3476.text:
be called in by the princes of the kingdom,
nor can he hope to be assisted in his designs

3482.text:
by the revolt of those whom the lord has around
him. This arises from the reasons given above;

3489.text:
for his ministers, being all slaves and bondmen,
can only be corrupted with great difficulty,

3495.text:
and one can expect little advantage from them
when they have been corrupted, as they cannot

3501.text:
carry the people with them, for the reasons
assigned. Hence, he who attacks the Turk must

3507.text:
bear in mind that he will find him united,
and he will have to rely more on his own strength

3513.text:
than on the revolt of others; but, if once
the Turk has been conquered, and routed in

3518.text:
the field in such a way that he cannot replace
his armies, there is nothing to fear but the

3523.text:
family of this prince, and, this being exterminated,
there remains no one to fear, the others having

3531.text:
no credit with the people; and as the conqueror
did not rely on them before his victory, so

3536.text:
he ought not to fear them after it.
The contrary happens in kingdoms governed

3542.text:
like that of France, because one can easily
enter there by gaining over some baron of

3547.text:
the kingdom, for one always finds malcontents
and such as desire a change. Such men, for

3554.text:
the reasons given, can open the way into the
state and render the victory easy; but if

3561.text:
you wish to hold it afterwards, you meet with
infinite difficulties, both from those who

3565.text:
have assisted you and from those you have
crushed. Nor is it enough for you to have

3570.text:
exterminated the family of the prince, because
the lords that remain make themselves the

3576.text:
heads of fresh movements against you, and
as you are unable either to satisfy or exterminate

3582.text:
them, that state is lost whenever time brings
the opportunity.

3588.text:
Now if you will consider what was the nature
of the government of Darius, you will find

3593.text:
it similar to the kingdom of the Turk, and
therefore it was only necessary for Alexander,

3599.text:
first to overthrow him in the field, and then
to take the country from him. After which

3604.text:
victory, Darius being killed, the state remained
secure to Alexander, for the above reasons.

3611.text:
And if his successors had been united they
would have enjoyed it securely and at their

3616.text:
ease, for there were no tumults raised in
the kingdom except those they provoked themselves.

3623.text:
But it is impossible to hold with such tranquillity
states constituted like that of France. Hence

3631.text:
arose those frequent rebellions against the
Romans in Spain, France, and Greece, owing

3637.text:
to the many principalities there were in these
states, of which, as long as the memory of

3643.text:
them endured, the Romans always held an insecure
possession; but with the power and long continuance

3650.text:
of the empire the memory of them passed away,
and the Romans then became secure possessors.

3656.text:
And when fighting afterwards amongst themselves,
each one was able to attach to himself his

3662.text:
own parts of the country, according to the
authority he had assumed there; and the family

3668.text:
of the former lord being exterminated, none
other than the Romans were acknowledged.

3675.text:
When these things are remembered no one will
marvel at the ease with which Alexander held

3680.text:
the Empire of Asia, or at the difficulties
which others have had to keep an acquisition,

3686.text:
such as Pyrrhus and many more; this is not
occasioned by the little or abundance of ability

3692.text:
in the conqueror, but by the want of uniformity
in the subject state.

3697.text:
End of Chapter IV
CHAPTER V — CONCERNING THE WAY TO GOVERN

3701.text:
CITIES OR PRINCIPALITIES WHICH LIVED UNDER
THEIR OWN LAWS BEFORE THEY WERE ANNEXED

3709.text:
Whenever those states which have been acquired
as stated have been accustomed to live under

3714.text:
their own laws and in freedom, there are three
courses for those who wish to hold them: the

3720.text:
first is to ruin them, the next is to reside
there in person, the third is to permit them

3725.text:
to live under their own laws, drawing a tribute,
and establishing within it an oligarchy which

3732.text:
will keep it friendly to you. Because such
a government, being created by the prince,

3738.text:
knows that it cannot stand without his friendship
and interest, and does it utmost to support

3743.text:
him; and therefore he who would keep a city
accustomed to freedom will hold it more easily

3749.text:
by the means of its own citizens than in any
other way.

3753.text:
There are, for example, the Spartans and the
Romans. The Spartans held Athens and Thebes,

3760.text:
establishing there an oligarchy, nevertheless
they lost them. The Romans, in order to hold

3767.text:
Capua, Carthage, and Numantia, dismantled
them, and did not lose them. They wished to

3773.text:
hold Greece as the Spartans held it, making
it free and permitting its laws, and did not

3779.text:
succeed. So to hold it they were compelled
to dismantle many cities in the country, for

3785.text:
in truth there is no safe way to retain them
otherwise than by ruining them. And he who

3792.text:
becomes master of a city accustomed to freedom
and does not destroy it, may expect to be

3798.text:
destroyed by it, for in rebellion it has always
the watchword of liberty and its ancient privileges

3805.text:
as a rallying point, which neither time nor
benefits will ever cause it to forget. And

3812.text:
whatever you may do or provide against, they
never forget that name or their privileges

3817.text:
unless they are disunited or dispersed, but
at every chance they immediately rally to

3824.text:
them, as Pisa after the hundred years she
had been held in bondage by the Florentines.

3829.text:
But when cities or countries are accustomed
to live under a prince, and his family is

3838.text:
exterminated, they, being on the one hand
accustomed to obey and on the other hand not

3843.text:
having the old prince, cannot agree in making
one from amongst themselves, and they do not

3849.text:
know how to govern themselves. For this reason
they are very slow to take up arms, and a

3855.text:
prince can gain them to himself and secure
them much more easily. But in republics there

3861.text:
is more vitality, greater hatred, and more
desire for vengeance, which will never permit

3867.text:
them to allow the memory of their former liberty
to rest; so that the safest way is to destroy

3872.text:
them or to reside there.
End of Chapter V

3877.text:
CHAPTER VI — CONCERNING NEW PRINCIPALITIES
WHICH ARE ACQUIRED BY ONE'S OWN ARMS AND ABILITY

3882.text:
Let no one be surprised if, in speaking of
entirely new principalities as I shall do,

3890.text:
I adduce the highest examples both of prince
and of state; because men, walking almost

3897.text:
always in paths beaten by others, and following
by imitation their deeds, are yet unable to

3904.text:
keep entirely to the ways of others or attain
to the power of those they imitate. A wise

3911.text:
man ought always to follow the paths beaten
by great men, and to imitate those who have

3917.text:
been supreme, so that if his ability does
not equal theirs, at least it will savour

3923.text:
of it. Let him act like the clever archers
who, designing to hit the mark which yet appears

3929.text:
too far distant, and knowing the limits to
which the strength of their bow attains, take

3935.text:
aim much higher than the mark, not to reach
by their strength or arrow to so great a height,

3941.text:
but to be able with the aid of so high an
aim to hit the mark they wish to reach.

3947.text:
I say, therefore, that in entirely new principalities,
where there is a new prince, more or less

3953.text:
difficulty is found in keeping them, accordingly
as there is more or less ability in him who

3959.text:
has acquired the state. Now, as the fact of
becoming a prince from a private station presupposes

3966.text:
either ability or fortune, it is clear that
one or other of these things will mitigate

3972.text:
in some degree many difficulties. Nevertheless,
he who has relied least on fortune is established

3979.text:
the strongest. Further, it facilitates matters
when the prince, having no other state, is

3986.text:
compelled to reside there in person.
But to come to those who, by their own ability

3992.text:
and not through fortune, have risen to be
princes, I say that Moses, Cyrus, Romulus,

3998.text:
Theseus, and such like are the most excellent
examples. And although one may not discuss

4004.text:
Moses, he having been a mere executor of the
will of God, yet he ought to be admired, if

4011.text:
only for that favour which made him worthy
to speak with God. But in considering Cyrus

4016.text:
and others who have acquired or founded kingdoms,
all will be found admirable; and if their

4022.text:
particular deeds and conduct shall be considered,
they will not be found inferior to those of

4028.text:
Moses, although he had so great a preceptor.
And in examining their actions and lives one

4035.text:
cannot see that they owed anything to fortune
beyond opportunity, which brought them the

4040.text:
material to mould into the form which seemed
best to them. Without that opportunity their

4046.text:
powers of mind would have been extinguished,
and without those powers the opportunity would

4052.text:
have come in vain.
It was necessary, therefore, to Moses that

4056.text:
he should find the people of Israel in Egypt
enslaved and oppressed by the Egyptians, in

4062.text:
order that they should be disposed to follow
him so as to be delivered out of bondage.

4068.text:
It was necessary that Romulus should not remain
in Alba, and that he should be abandoned at

4074.text:
his birth, in order that he should become
King of Rome and founder of the fatherland.

4080.text:
It was necessary that Cyrus should find the
Persians discontented with the government

4085.text:
of the Medes, and the Medes soft and effeminate
through their long peace. Theseus could not

4091.text:
have shown his ability had he not found the
Athenians dispersed. These opportunities,

4098.text:
therefore, made those men fortunate, and their
high ability enabled them to recognize the

4103.text:
opportunity whereby their country was ennobled
and made famous.

4109.text:
Those who by valorous ways become princes,
like these men, acquire a principality with

4115.text:
difficulty, but they keep it with ease. The
difficulties they have in acquiring it rise

4121.text:
in part from the new rules and methods which
they are forced to introduce to establish

4126.text:
their government and its security. And it
ought to be remembered that there is nothing

4132.text:
more difficult to take in hand, more perilous
to conduct, or more uncertain in its success,

4138.text:
than to take the lead in the introduction
of a new order of things, because the innovator

4143.text:
has for enemies all those who have done well
under the old conditions, and lukewarm defenders

4150.text:
in those who may do well under the new. This
coolness arises partly from fear of the opponents,

4158.text:
who have the laws on their side, and partly
from the incredulity of men, who do not readily

4164.text:
believe in new things until they have had
a long experience of them. Thus it happens

4170.text:
that whenever those who are hostile have the
opportunity to attack they do it like partisans,

4176.text:
whilst the others defend lukewarmly, in such
wise that the prince is endangered along with

4182.text:
them.
It is necessary, therefore, if we desire to

4186.text:
discuss this matter thoroughly, to inquire
whether these innovators can rely on themselves

4192.text:
or have to depend on others: that is to say,
whether, to consummate their enterprise, have

4199.text:
they to use prayers or can they use force?
In the first instance they always succeed

4204.text:
badly, and never compass anything; but when
they can rely on themselves and use force,

4211.text:
then they are rarely endangered. Hence it
is that all armed prophets have conquered,

4217.text:
and the unarmed ones have been destroyed.
Besides the reasons mentioned, the nature

4222.text:
of the people is variable, and whilst it is
easy to persuade them, it is difficult to

4228.text:
fix them in that persuasion. And thus it is
necessary to take such measures that, when

4234.text:
they believe no longer, it may be possible
to make them believe by force.

4241.text:
If Moses, Cyrus, Theseus, and Romulus had
been unarmed they could not have enforced

4247.text:
their constitutions for long—as happened
in our time to Fra Girolamo Savonarola, who

4254.text:
was ruined with his new order of things immediately
the multitude believed in him no longer, and

4260.text:
he had no means of keeping steadfast those
who believed or of making the unbelievers

4266.text:
to believe. Therefore such as these have great
difficulties in consummating their enterprise,

4273.text:
for all their dangers are in the ascent, yet
with ability they will overcome them; but

4278.text:
when these are overcome, and those who envied
them their success are exterminated, they

4284.text:
will begin to be respected, and they will
continue afterwards powerful, secure, honoured,

4290.text:
and happy.
To these great examples I wish to add a lesser

4295.text:
one; still it bears some resemblance to them,
and I wish it to suffice me for all of a like

4300.text:
kind: it is Hiero the Syracusan. This man
rose from a private station to be Prince of

4318.text:
Syracuse, nor did he, either, owe anything
to fortune but opportunity; for the Syracusans,

4325.text:
being oppressed, chose him for their captain,
afterwards he was rewarded by being made their

4330.text:
prince. He was of so great ability, even as
a private citizen, that one who writes of

4336.text:
him says he wanted nothing but a kingdom to
be a king. This man abolished the old soldiery,

4343.text:
organized the new, gave up old alliances,
made new ones; and as he had his own soldiers

4349.text:
and allies, on such foundations he was able
to build any edifice: thus, whilst he had

4356.text:
endured much trouble in acquiring, he had
but little in keeping.

4364.text:
End of Chapter VI
CHAPTER VII — CONCERNING NEW PRINCIPALITIES

4371.text:
WHICH ARE ACQUIRED EITHER BY THE ARMS OF OTHERS
OR BY GOOD FORTUNE

4377.text:
Those who solely by good fortune become princes
from being private citizens have little trouble

4382.text:
in rising, but much in keeping atop; they
have not any difficulties on the way up, because

4389.text:
they fly, but they have many when they reach
the summit. Such are those to whom some state

4394.text:
is given either for money or by the favour
of him who bestows it; as happened to many

4401.text:
in Greece, in the cities of Ionia and of the
Hellespont, where princes were made by Darius,

4407.text:
in order that they might hold the cities both
for his security and his glory; as also were

4412.text:
those emperors who, by the corruption of the
soldiers, from being citizens came to empire.

4419.text:
Such stand simply elevated upon the goodwill
and the fortune of him who has elevated them—two

4426.text:
most inconstant and unstable things. Neither
have they the knowledge requisite for the

4432.text:
position; because, unless they are men of
great worth and ability, it is not reasonable

4438.text:
to expect that they should know how to command,
having always lived in a private condition;

4444.text:
besides, they cannot hold it because they
have not forces which they can keep friendly

4450.text:
and faithful.
States that rise unexpectedly, then, like

4455.text:
all other things in nature which are born
and grow rapidly, cannot leave their foundations

4461.text:
and correspondencies [Footnote: "Le radici
e corrispondenze," their roots (i.e. foundations)

4469.text:
and correspondencies or relations with other
states—a common meaning of "correspondence"

4475.text:
and "correspondency" in the sixteenth and
seventeenth centuries] cannot leave their

4480.text:
foundations and correspondencies fixed in
such a way that the first storm will not overthrow

4487.text:
them; unless, as is said, those who unexpectedly
become princes are men of so much ability

4494.text:
that they know they have to be prepared at
once to hold that which fortune has thrown

4499.text:
into their laps, and that those foundations,
which others have laid BEFORE they became

4506.text:
princes, they must lay AFTERWARDS.
Concerning these two methods of rising to

4513.text:
be a prince by ability or fortune, I wish
to adduce two examples within our own recollection,

4520.text:
and these are Francesco Sforza [Footnote:
Francesco Sforza, born 1401, died 1466. He

4529.text:
married Bianca Maria Visconti, a natural daughter
of Filippo Visconti, the Duke of Milan, on

4536.text:
whose death he procured his own elevation
to the duchy. Machiavelli was the accredited

4542.text:
agent of the Florentine Republic to Cesare
Borgia (1478-1507) during the transactions

4550.text:
which led up to the assassinations of the
Orsini and Vitelli at Sinigalia, and along

4556.text:
with his letters to his chiefs in Florence
he has left an account, written ten years

4562.text:
before "The Prince," of the proceedings of
the duke in his "Descritione del modo tenuto

4568.text:
dal duca Valentino nello ammazzare Vitellozzo
Vitelli," etc., a translation of which is

4578.text:
I wish to adduce two examples within our own
recollection, and these are Francesco Sforza

4585.text:
and Cesare Borgia. Francesco, by proper means
and with great ability, from being a private

4592.text:
person rose to be Duke of Milan, and that
which he had acquired with a thousand anxieties

4598.text:
he kept with little trouble. On the other
hand, Cesare Borgia, called by the people

4604.text:
Duke Valentino, acquired his state during
the ascendancy of his father, and on its decline

4610.text:
he lost it, notwithstanding that he had taken
every measure and done all that ought to be

4616.text:
done by a wise and able man to fix firmly
his roots in the states which the arms and

4622.text: fortunes of others had bestowed on him.

4626.text:
Because, as is stated above, he who has not
first laid his foundations may be able with

4633.text:
great ability to lay them afterwards, but
they will be laid with trouble to the architect

4638.text:
and danger to the building. If, therefore,
all the steps taken by the duke be considered,

4645.text:
it will be seen that he laid solid foundations
for his future power, and I do not consider

4650.text:
it superfluous to discuss them, because I
do not know what better precepts to give a

4656.text:
new prince than the example of his actions;
and if his dispositions were of no avail,

4662.text:
that was not his fault, but the extraordinary
and extreme malignity of fortune.

4670.text:
Alexander the Sixth, in wishing to aggrandize
the duke, his son, had many immediate and

4676.text:
prospective difficulties. Firstly, he did
not see his way to make him master of any

4681.text:
state that was not a state of the Church;
and if he was willing to rob the Church he

4686.text:
knew that the Duke of Milan and the Venetians
would not consent, because Faenza and Rimini

4692.text:
were already under the protection of the Venetians.
Besides this, he saw the arms of Italy, especially

4700.text:
those by which he might have been assisted,
in hands that would fear the aggrandizement

4705.text:
of the Pope, namely, the Orsini and the Colonnesi
and their following. It behoved him, therefore,

4712.text:
to upset this state of affairs and embroil
the powers, so as to make himself securely

4718.text:
master of part of their states. This was easy
for him to do, because he found the Venetians,

4725.text:
moved by other reasons, inclined to bring
back the French into Italy; he would not only

4731.text:
not oppose this, but he would render it more
easy by dissolving the former marriage of

4737.text:
King Louis. Therefore the king came into Italy
with the assistance of the Venetians and the

4743.text:
consent of Alexander. He was no sooner in
Milan than the Pope had soldiers from him

4750.text:
for the attempt on the Romagna, which yielded
to him on the reputation of the king. The

4755.text:
duke, therefore, having acquired the Romagna
and beaten the Colonnesi, while wishing to

4761.text:
hold that and to advance further, was hindered
by two things: the one, his forces did not

4768.text:
appear loyal to him, the other, the goodwill
of France: that is to say, he feared that

4773.text:
the forces of the Orsini, which he was using,
would not stand to him, that not only might

4779.text:
they hinder him from winning more, but might
themselves seize what he had won, and that

4784.text:
the king might also do the same. Of the Orsini
he had a warning when, after taking Faenza

4792.text:
and attacking Bologna, he saw them go very
unwillingly to that attack. And as to the

4798.text:
king, he learned his mind when he himself,
after taking the Duchy of Urbino, attacked

4805.text:
Tuscany, and the king made him desist from
that undertaking; hence the duke decided to

4811.text:
depend no more upon the arms and the luck
of others.

4816.text:
For the first thing he weakened the Orsini
and Colonnesi parties in Rome, by gaining

4822.text:
to himself all their adherents who were gentlemen,
making them his gentlemen, giving them good

4829.text:
pay, and, according to their rank, honouring
them with office and command in such a way

4834.text:
that in a few months all attachment to the
factions was destroyed and turned entirely

4840.text:
to the duke. After this he awaited an opportunity
to crush the Orsini, having scattered the

4846.text:
adherents of the Colonna house. This came
to him soon and he used it well; for the Orsini,

4853.text:
perceiving at length that the aggrandizement
of the duke and the Church was ruin to them,

4859.text:
called a meeting of the Magione in Perugia.
From this sprung the rebellion at Urbino and

4866.text:
the tumults in the Romagna, with endless dangers
to the duke, all of which he overcame with

4872.text:
the help of the French. Having restored his
authority, not to leave it at risk by trusting

4879.text:
either to the French or other outside forces,
he had recourse to his wiles, and he knew

4885.text:
so well how to conceal his mind that, by the
mediation of Signor Pagolo—whom the duke

4892.text:
did not fail to secure with all kinds of attention,
giving him money, apparel, and horses—the

4899.text:
Orsini were reconciled, so that their simplicity
brought them into his power at Sinigalia.

4907.text:
[Footnote: Sinigalia, 31st December 1502.]
Having exterminated the leaders, and turned

4916.text:
their partisans into his friends, the duke
laid sufficiently good foundations to his

4922.text:
power, having all the Romagna and the Duchy
of Urbino; and the people now beginning to

4927.text:
appreciate their prosperity, he gained them
all over to himself. And as this point is

4933.text:
worthy of notice, and to be imitated by others,
I am not willing to leave it out.

4939.text:
When the duke occupied the Romagna he found
it under the rule of weak masters, who rather

4946.text:
plundered their subjects than ruled them,
and gave them more cause for disunion than

4952.text:
for union, so that the country was full of
robbery, quarrels, and every kind of violence;

4958.text:
and so, wishing to bring back peace and obedience
to authority, he considered it necessary to

4965.text:
give it a good governor. Thereupon he promoted
Messer Ramiro d'Orco, [Footnote: Ramiro d'Orco.

4975.text:
Ramiro de Lorqua.]
Therefore he promoted Messer Ramiro d'Orco

4981.text:
a swift and cruel man, to whom he gave the
fullest power. This man in a short time restored

4989.text:
peace and unity with the greatest success.
Afterwards the duke considered that it was

4995.text:
not advisable to confer such excessive authority,
for he had no doubt but that he would become

5000.text:
odious, so he set up a court of judgment in
the country, under a most excellent president,

5007.text:
wherein all cities had their advocates. And
because he knew that the past severity had

5013.text:
caused some hatred against himself, so, to
clear himself in the minds of the people,

5020.text:
and gain them entirely to himself, he desired
to show that, if any cruelty had been practised,

5026.text:
it had not originated with him, but in the
natural sternness of the minister. Under this

5033.text:
pretence he took Ramiro, and one morning caused
him to be executed and left on the piazza

5039.text:
at Cesena with the block and a bloody knife
at his side. The barbarity of this spectacle

5046.text:
caused the people to be at once satisfied
and dismayed.

5051.text:
But let us return whence we started. I say
that the duke, finding himself now sufficiently

5057.text:
powerful and partly secured from immediate
dangers by having armed himself in his own

5063.text:
way, and having in a great measure crushed
those forces in his vicinity that could injure

5069.text:
him if he wished to proceed with his conquest,
had next to consider France, for he knew that

5075.text:
the king, who too late was aware of his mistake,
would not support him. And from this time

5082.text:
he began to seek new alliances and to temporize
with France in the expedition which she was

5089.text:
making towards the kingdom of Naples against
the Spaniards who were besieging Gaeta. It

5095.text:
was his intention to secure himself against
them, and this he would have quickly accomplished

5100.text:
had Alexander lived.
Such was his line of action as to present

5105.text:
affairs. But as to the future he had to fear,
in the first place, that a new successor to

5112.text:
the Church might not be friendly to him and
might seek to take from him that which Alexander

5118.text:
had given him, so he decided to act in four
ways. Firstly, by exterminating the families

5125.text:
of those lords whom he had despoiled, so as
to take away that pretext from the Pope. Secondly,

5132.text:
by winning to himself all the gentlemen of
Rome, so as to be able to curb the Pope with

5138.text:
their aid, as has been observed. Thirdly,
by converting the college more to himself.

5145.text:
Fourthly, by acquiring so much power before
the Pope should die that he could by his own

5151.text:
measures resist the first shock. Of these
four things, at the death of Alexander, he

5158.text:
had accomplished three. For he had killed
