as many of the dispossessed lords as he could

5164.text:
lay hands on, and few had escaped; he had
won over the Roman gentlemen, and he had the

5170.text:
most numerous party in the college. And as
to any fresh acquisition, he intended to become

5177.text:
master of Tuscany, for he already possessed
Perugia and Piombino, and Pisa was under his

5183.text:
protection. And as he had no longer to study
France (for the French were already driven

5189.text:
out of the kingdom of Naples by the Spaniards,
and in this way both were compelled to buy

5194.text:
his goodwill), he pounced down upon Pisa.
After this, Lucca and Siena yielded at once,

5203.text:
partly through hatred and partly through fear
of the Florentines; and the Florentines would

5208.text:
have had no remedy had he continued to prosper,
as he was prospering the year that Alexander

5214.text:
died, for he had acquired so much power and
reputation that he would have stood by himself,

5220.text:
and no longer have depended on the luck and
the forces of others, but solely on his own

5226.text:
power and ability.
But Alexander died five years after he had

5232.text:
first drawn the sword. He left the duke with
the state of Romagna alone consolidated, with

5238.text:
the rest in the air, between two most powerful
hostile armies, and sick unto death. Yet there

5246.text:
were in the duke such boldness and ability,
and he knew so well how men are to be won

5252.text:
or lost, and so firm were the foundations
which in so short a time he had laid, that

5258.text:
if he had not had those armies on his back,
or if he had been in good health, he would

5263.text:
have overcome all difficulties. And it is
seen that his foundations were good, for the

5270.text:
Romagna awaited him for more than a month.
In Rome, although but half alive, he remained

5276.text:
secure; and whilst the Baglioni, the Vitelli,
and the Orsini might come to Rome, they could

5283.text:
not effect anything against him. If he could
not have made Pope him whom he wished, at

5289.text:
least the one whom he did not wish would not
have been elected. But if he had been in sound

5295.text:
health at the death of Alexander, [Footnote:
Alexander VI died of fever, 18th August 1503.]

5306.text:
But if he had been in sound health at the
death of Alexander, everything would have

5310.text:
been different to him. On the day that Julius
the Second [Footnote: Julius II was Giuliano

5318.text:
della Rovere, Cardinal of San Pietro ad Vincula,
born 1443, died 1513.] On the day that Julius

5329.text:
the Second was elected, he told me that he
had thought of everything that might occur

5334.text:
at the death of his father, and had provided
a remedy for all, except that he had never

5340.text:
anticipated that, when the death did happen,
he himself would be on the point to die.

5347.text:
When all the actions of the duke are recalled,
I do not know how to blame him, but rather

5352.text:
it appears to be, as I have said, that I ought
to offer him for imitation to all those who,

5358.text:
by the fortune or the arms of others, are
raised to government. Because he, having a

5364.text:
lofty spirit and far-reaching aims, could
not have regulated his conduct otherwise,

5370.text:
and only the shortness of the life of Alexander
and his own sickness frustrated his designs.

5377.text:
Therefore, he who considers it necessary to
secure himself in his new principality, to

5384.text:
win friends, to overcome either by force or
fraud, to make himself beloved and feared

5390.text:
by the people, to be followed and revered
by the soldiers, to exterminate those who

5396.text:
have power or reason to hurt him, to change
the old order of things for new, to be severe

5402.text:
and gracious, magnanimous and liberal, to
destroy a disloyal soldiery and to create

5409.text:
new, to maintain friendship with kings and
princes in such a way that they must help

5415.text:
him with zeal and offend with caution, cannot
find a more lively example than the actions

5423.text:
of this man.
Only can he be blamed for the election of

5428.text:
Julius the Second, in whom he made a bad choice,
because, as is said, not being able to elect

5434.text:
a Pope to his own mind, he could have hindered
any other from being elected Pope; and he

5440.text:
ought never to have consented to the election
of any cardinal whom he had injured or who

5445.text:
had cause to fear him if they became pontiffs.
For men injure either from fear or hatred.

5452.text:
Those whom he had injured, amongst others,
were San Pietro ad Vincula, Colonna, San Giorgio,

5459.text:
and Ascanio. [Footnote: San Giorgio is Raffaello
Riario. Ascanio is Ascanio Sforza]. The rest,

5472.text:
in becoming Pope, had to fear him, Rouen and
the Spaniards excepted; the latter from their

5479.text:
relationship and obligations, the former from
his influence, the kingdom of France having

5485.text:
relations with him. Therefore, above everything,
the duke ought to have created a Spaniard

5491.text:
Pope, and, failing him, he ought to have consented
to Rouen and not San Pietro ad Vincula. He

5499.text:
who believes that new benefits will cause
great personages to forget old injuries is

5504.text:
deceived. Therefore, the duke erred in his
choice, and it was the cause of his ultimate

5516.text:
CHAPTER VIII — CONCERNING THOSE WHO HAVE
OBTAINED A PRINCIPALITY BY WICKEDNESS

5522.text:
Although a prince may rise from a private
station in two ways, neither of which can

5527.text:
be entirely attributed to fortune or genius,
yet it is manifest to me that I must not be

5534.text:
silent on them, although one could be more
copiously treated when I discuss republics.

5540.text:
These methods are when, either by some wicked
or nefarious ways, one ascends to the principality,

5547.text:
or when by the favour of his fellow-citizens
a private person becomes the prince of his

5553.text:
country. And speaking of the first method,
it will be illustrated by two examples—one

5559.text:
ancient, the other modern—and without entering
further into the subject, I consider these

5564.text:
two examples will suffice those who may be
compelled to follow them.

5569.text:
Agathocles, the Sicilian, [Footnote: Agathocles
the Sicilian, born 361 B.C., died 289 B.C.]

5582.text:
Agathocles, the Sicilian, became King of Syracuse
not only from a private but from a low and

5590.text:
abject position. This man, the son of a potter,
through all the changes in his fortunes always

5597.text:
led an infamous life. Nevertheless, he accompanied
his infamies with so much ability of mind

5604.text:
and body that, having devoted himself to the
military profession, he rose through its ranks

5610.text:
to be Praetor of Syracuse. Being established
in that position, and having deliberately

5616.text:
resolved to make himself prince and to seize
by violence, without obligation to others,

5623.text:
that which had been conceded to him by assent,
he came to an understanding for this purpose

5629.text:
with Amilcar, the Carthaginian, who, with
his army, was fighting in Sicily. One morning

5636.text:
he assembled the people and the senate of
Syracuse, as if he had to discuss with them

5641.text:
things relating to the Republic, and at a
given signal the soldiers killed all the senators

5647.text:
and the richest of the people; these dead,
he seized and held the princedom of that city

5653.text:
without any civil commotion. And although
he was twice routed by the Carthaginians,

5659.text:
and ultimately besieged, yet not only was
he able to defend his city, but leaving part

5665.text:
of his men for its defence, with the others
he attacked Africa, and in a short time raised

5671.text:
the siege of Syracuse. The Carthaginians,
reduced to extreme necessity, were compelled

5678.text:
to come to terms with Agathocles, and, leaving
Sicily to him, had to be content with the

5686.text:
Therefore, he who considers the actions and
the genius of this man will see nothing, or

5693.text:
little, which can be attributed to fortune,
inasmuch as he attained pre-eminence, as is

5699.text:
shown above, not by the favour of any one,
but step by step in the military profession,

5705.text:
which steps were gained with a thousand troubles
and perils, and were afterwards boldly held

5711.text:
by him with many hazardous dangers. Yet it
cannot be called talent to slay fellow-citizens,

5719.text:
to deceive friends, to be without faith, without
mercy, without religion; such methods may

5726.text:
gain empire, but not glory. Still, if the
courage of Agathocles in entering into and

5734.text:
extricating himself from dangers be considered,
together with his greatness of mind in enduring

5741.text:
and overcoming hardships, it cannot be seen
why he should be esteemed less than the most

5747.text:
notable captain. Nevertheless, his barbarous
cruelty and inhumanity with infinite wickedness

5755.text:
do not permit him to be celebrated among the
most excellent men. What he achieved cannot

5761.text:
be attributed either to fortune or genius.
In our times, during the rule of Alexander

5769.text:
the Sixth, Oliverotto da Fermo, having been
left an orphan many years before, was brought

5776.text:
up by his maternal uncle, Giovanni Fogliani,
and in the early days of his youth sent to

5783.text:
fight under Pagolo Vitelli, that, being trained
under his discipline, he might attain some

5790.text:
high position in the military profession.
After Pagolo died, he fought under his brother

5797.text:
Vitellozzo, and in a very short time, being
endowed with wit and a vigorous body and mind,

5804.text:
he became the first man in his profession.
But it appearing a paltry thing to serve under

5810.text:
others, he resolved, with the aid of some
citizens of Fermo, to whom the slavery of

5816.text:
their country was dearer than its liberty,
and with the help of the Vitelleschi, to seize

5821.text:
Fermo. So he wrote to Giovanni Fogliani that,
having been away from home for many years,

5829.text:
he wished to visit him and his city, and in
some measure to look upon his patrimony; and

5835.text:
although he had not laboured to acquire anything
except honour, yet, in order that the citizens

5841.text:
should see he had not spent his time in vain,
he desired to come honourably, so would be

5847.text:
accompanied by one hundred horsemen, his friends
and retainers; and he entreated Giovanni to

5853.text:
arrange that he should be received honourably
by the Fermians, all of which would be not

5858.text:
only to his honour, but also to that of Giovanni
himself, who had brought him up.

5865.text:
Giovanni, therefore, did not fail in any attentions
due to his nephew, and he caused him to be

5871.text:
honourably received by the Fermians, and he
lodged him in his own house, where, having

5877.text:
passed some days, and having arranged what
was necessary for his wicked designs, Oliverotto

5882.text:
gave a solemn banquet to which he invited
Giovanni Fogliani and the chiefs of Fermo.

5890.text:
When the viands and all the other entertainments
that are usual in such banquets were finished,

5896.text:
Oliverotto artfully began certain grave discourses,
speaking of the greatness of Pope Alexander

5902.text:
and his son Cesare, and of their enterprises,
to which discourse Giovanni and others answered;

5910.text:
but he rose at once, saying that such matters
ought to be discussed in a more private place,

5916.text:
and he betook himself to a chamber, whither
Giovanni and the rest of the citizens went

5921.text:
in after him. No sooner were they seated than
soldiers issued from secret places and slaughtered

5928.text:
Giovanni and the rest. After these murders
Oliverotto, mounted on horseback, rode up

5935.text:
and down the town and besieged the chief magistrate
in the palace, so that in fear the people

5942.text:
were forced to obey him, and to form a government,
of which he made himself the prince. He killed

5948.text:
all the malcontents who were able to injure
him, and strengthened himself with new civil

5954.text:
and military ordinances, in such a way that,
in the year during which he held the principality,

5961.text:
not only was he secure in the city of Fermo,
but he had become formidable to all his neighbours.

5968.text:
And his destruction would have been as difficult
as that of Agathocles if he had not allowed

5973.text:
himself to be overreached by Cesare Borgia,
who took him with the Orsini and Vitelli at

5979.text:
Sinigalia, as was stated above. Thus one year
after he had committed this parricide, he

5986.text:
was strangled, together with Vitellozzo, whom
he had made his leader in valour and wickedness.

5992.text:
Some may wonder how it can happen that Agathocles,
and his like, after infinite treacheries and

6000.text:
cruelties, should live for long secure in
his country, and defend himself from external

6006.text:
enemies, and never be conspired against by
his own citizens; seeing that many others,

6012.text:
by means of cruelty, have never been able
even in peaceful times to hold the state,

6017.text:
still less in the doubtful times of war. I
believe that this follows from severities

6023.text:
[Footnote: Mr Burd suggests that this word
probably comes near the modern equivalent

6029.text:
of Machiavelli's thought when he speaks of
"crudelta" than the more obvious "cruelties."]

6037.text:
I believe that this follows from severities
being badly or properly used. Those may be

6043.text:
called properly used, if of evil it is possible
to speak well, that are applied at one blow

6050.text:
and are necessary to one's security, and that
are not persisted in afterwards unless they

6056.text:
can be turned to the advantage of the subjects.
The badly employed are those which, notwithstanding

6063.text:
they may be few in the commencement, multiply
with time rather than decrease. Those who

6069.text:
practise the first system are able, by aid
of God or man, to mitigate in some degree

6076.text:
their rule, as Agathocles did. It is impossible
for those who follow the other to maintain

6083.text:
Hence it is to be remarked that, in seizing
a state, the usurper ought to examine closely

6090.text:
into all those injuries which it is necessary
for him to inflict, and to do them all at

6096.text:
one stroke so as not to have to repeat them
daily; and thus by not unsettling men he will

6102.text:
be able to reassure them, and win them to
himself by benefits. He who does otherwise,

6109.text:
either from timidity or evil advice, is always
compelled to keep the knife in his hand; neither

6116.text:
can he rely on his subjects, nor can they
attach themselves to him, owing to their continued

6122.text:
and repeated wrongs. For injuries ought to
be done all at one time, so that, being tasted

6130.text:
less, they offend less; benefits ought to
be given little by little, so that the flavour

6137.text:
of them may last longer.
And above all things, a prince ought to live

6142.text:
amongst his people in such a way that no unexpected
circumstances, whether of good or evil, shall

6150.text:
make him change; because if the necessity
for this comes in troubled times, you are

6155.text:
too late for harsh measures; and mild ones
will not help you, for they will be considered

6161.text:
as forced from you, and no one will be under
any obligation to you for them.

6168.text:
End of Chapter VIII
CHAPTER IX — CONCERNING A CIVIL PRINCIPALITY

6177.text:
But coming to the other point—where a leading
citizen becomes the prince of his country,

6182.text:
not by wickedness or any intolerable violence,
but by the favour of his fellow citizens—this

6189.text:
may be called a civil principality: nor is
genius or fortune altogether necessary to

6195.text:
attain to it, but rather a happy shrewdness.
I say then that such a principality is obtained

6202.text:
either by the favour of the people or by the
favour of the nobles. Because in all cities

6208.text:
these two distinct parties are found, and
from this it arises that the people do not

6214.text:
wish to be ruled nor oppressed by the nobles,
and the nobles wish to rule and oppress the

6221.text:
people; and from these two opposite desires
there arises in cities one of three results,

6228.text:
either a principality, self-government, or
anarchy.

6233.text:
A principality is created either by the people
or by the nobles, accordingly as one or other

6239.text:
of them has the opportunity; for the nobles,
seeing they cannot withstand the people, begin

6246.text:
to cry up the reputation of one of themselves,
and they make him a prince, so that under

6251.text:
his shadow they can give vent to their ambitions.
The people, finding they cannot resist the

6258.text:
nobles, also cry up the reputation of one
of themselves, and make him a prince so as

6263.text:
to be defended by his authority. He who obtains
sovereignty by the assistance of the nobles

6271.text:
maintains himself with more difficulty than
he who comes to it by the aid of the people,

6277.text:
because the former finds himself with many
around him who consider themselves his equals,

6283.text:
and because of this he can neither rule nor
manage them to his liking. But he who reaches

6288.text:
sovereignty by popular favour finds himself
alone, and has none around him, or few, who

6295.text:
are not prepared to obey him.
Besides this, one cannot by fair dealing,

6301.text:
and without injury to others, satisfy the
nobles, but you can satisfy the people, for

6307.text:
their object is more righteous than that of
the nobles, the latter wishing to oppress,

6313.text:
while the former only desire not to be oppressed.
It is to be added also that a prince can never

6320.text:
secure himself against a hostile people, because
of their being too many, whilst from the nobles

6326.text:
he can secure himself, as they are few in
number. The worst that a prince may expect

6332.text:
from a hostile people is to be abandoned by
them; but from hostile nobles he has not only

6339.text:
to fear abandonment, but also that they will
rise against him; for they, being in these

6344.text:
affairs more far-seeing and astute, always
come forward in time to save themselves, and

6351.text:
to obtain favours from him whom they expect
to prevail. Further, the prince is compelled

6357.text:
to live always with the same people, but he
can do well without the same nobles, being

6363.text:
able to make and unmake them daily, and to
give or take away authority when it pleases

6369.text:
him.
Therefore, to make this point clearer, I say

6373.text:
that the nobles ought to be looked at mainly
in two ways: that is to say, they either shape

6379.text:
their course in such a way as binds them entirely
to your fortune, or they do not. Those who

6386.text:
so bind themselves, and are not rapacious,
ought to be honoured and loved; those who

6392.text:
do not bind themselves may be dealt with in
two ways; they may fail to do this through

6398.text:
pusillanimity and a natural want of courage,
in which case you ought to make use of them,

6404.text:
especially of those who are of good counsel;
and thus, whilst in prosperity you honour

6410.text:
them, in adversity you do not have to fear
them. But when for their own ambitious ends

6416.text:
they shun binding themselves, it is a token
that they are giving more thought to themselves

6422.text:
than to you, and a prince ought to guard against
such, and to fear them as if they were open

6428.text:
enemies, because in adversity they always
help to ruin him.

6433.text:
Therefore, one who becomes a prince through
the favour of the people ought to keep them

6439.text:
friendly, and this he can easily do seeing
they only ask not to be oppressed by him.

6445.text:
But one who, in opposition to the people,
becomes a prince by the favour of the nobles,

6451.text:
ought, above everything, to seek to win the
people over to himself, and this he may easily

6457.text:
do if he takes them under his protection.
Because men, when they receive good from him

6463.text:
of whom they were expecting evil, are bound
more closely to their benefactor; thus the

6469.text:
people quickly become more devoted to him
than if he had been raised to the principality

6475.text:
by their favours; and the prince can win their
affections in many ways, but as these vary

6481.text:
according to the circumstances one cannot
give fixed rules, so I omit them; but, I repeat,

6488.text:
it is necessary for a prince to have the people
friendly, otherwise he has no security in

6494.text:
adversity.
Nabis, [Footnote: Nabis, tyrant of Sparta,

6501.text:
conquered by the Romans under Flamininus in
195 B.C.; killed 192 B.C.] Nabis, Prince of

6511.text:
the Spartans, sustained the attack of all
Greece, and of a victorious Roman army, and

6517.text:
against them he defended his country and his
government; and for the overcoming of this

6523.text:
peril it was only necessary for him to make
himself secure against a few, but this would

6529.text:
not have been sufficient had the people been
hostile. And do not let any one impugn this

6535.text:
statement with the trite proverb that "He
who builds on the people, builds on the mud,"

6541.text:
for this is true when a private citizen makes
a foundation there, and persuades himself

6546.text:
that the people will free him when he is oppressed
by his enemies or by the magistrates; wherein

6552.text:
he would find himself very often deceived,
as happened to the Gracchi in Rome and to

6558.text:
Messer Giorgio Scali in Florence [Footnote:
Messer Giorgio Scali. This event is to be

6566.text:
found in Machiavelli's "Florentine History,"
Book III.] But granted a prince who has established

6573.text:
himself as above, who can command, and is
a man of courage, undismayed in adversity,

6580.text:
who does not fail in other qualifications,
and who, by his resolution and energy, keeps

6586.text:
the whole people encouraged—such a one will
never find himself deceived in them, and it

6591.text:
will be shown that he has laid his foundations
well.

6596.text:
These principalities are liable to danger
when they are passing from the civil to the

6601.text:
absolute order of government, for such princes
either rule personally or through magistrates.

6609.text:
In the latter case their government is weaker
and more insecure, because it rests entirely

6615.text:
on the goodwill of those citizens who are
raised to the magistracy, and who, especially

6621.text:
in troubled times, can destroy the government
with great ease, either by intrigue or open

6627.text:
defiance; and the prince has not the chance
amid tumults to exercise absolute authority,

6634.text:
because the citizens and subjects, accustomed
to receive orders from magistrates, are not

6639.text:
of a mind to obey him amid these confusions,
and there will always be in doubtful times

6645.text:
a scarcity of men whom he can trust. For such
a prince cannot rely upon what he observes

6652.text:
in quiet times, when citizens have need of
the state, because then every one agrees with

6658.text:
him; they all promise, and when death is far
distant they all wish to die for him; but

6664.text:
in troubled times, when the state has need
of its citizens, then he finds but few. And

6671.text:
so much the more is this experiment dangerous,
inasmuch as it can only be tried once. Therefore

6678.text:
a wise prince ought to adopt such a course
that his citizens will always in every sort

6684.text:
and kind of circumstance have need of the
state and of him, and then he will always

6689.text:
find them faithful.
End of Chapter IX

6694.text:
CHAPTER X — CONCERNING THE WAY IN WHICH
THE STRENGTH OF ALL PRINCIPALITIES OUGHT TO

6698.text:
BE MEASURED
It is necessary to consider another point

6702.text:
in examining the character of these principalities:
that is, whether a prince has such power that,

6709.text:
in case of need, he can support himself with
his own resources, or whether he has always

6715.text:
need of the assistance of others. And to make
this quite clear I say that I consider those

6721.text:
who are able to support themselves by their
own resources who can, either by abundance

6726.text:
of men or money, raise a sufficient army to
join battle against any one who comes to attack

6733.text:
them; and I consider those always to have
need of others who cannot show themselves

6738.text:
against the enemy in the field, but are forced
to defend themselves by sheltering behind

6744.text:
walls. The first case has been discussed,
but we will speak of it again should it recur.

6750.text:
In the second case one can say nothing except
to encourage such princes to provision and

6756.text:
fortify their towns, and not on any account
to defend the country. And whoever shall fortify

6763.text:
his town well, and shall have managed the
other concerns of his subjects in the way

6768.text:
stated above, and to be often repeated, will
never be attacked without great caution, for

6774.text:
men are always adverse to enterprises where
difficulties can be seen, and it will be seen

6780.text:
not to be an easy thing to attack one who
has his town well fortified, and is not hated

6786.text:
by his people.
The cities of Germany are absolutely free,

6792.text:
they own but little country around them, and
they yield obedience to the emperor when it

6797.text:
suits them, nor do they fear this or any other
power they may have near them, because they

6803.text:
are fortified in such a way that every one
thinks the taking of them by assault would

6809.text:
be tedious and difficult, seeing they have
proper ditches and walls, they have sufficient

6815.text:
artillery, and they always keep in public
depots enough for one year's eating, drinking,

6821.text:
and firing. And beyond this, to keep the people
quiet and without loss to the state, they

6827.text:
always have the means of giving work to the
community in those labours that are the life

6832.text:
and strength of the city, and on the pursuit
of which the people are supported; they also

6838.text:
hold military exercises in repute, and moreover
have many ordinances to uphold them.

6845.text:
Therefore, a prince who has a strong city,
and had not made himself odious, will not

6851.text:
be attacked, or if any one should attack he
will only be driven off with disgrace; again,

6858.text:
because that the affairs of this world are
so changeable, it is almost impossible to

6863.text:
keep an army a whole year in the field without
being interfered with. And whoever should

6869.text:
reply: If the people have property outside
the city, and see it burnt, they will not

6874.text:
remain patient, and the long siege and self-interest
will make them forget their prince; to this

6881.text:
I answer that a powerful and courageous prince
will overcome all such difficulties by giving

6887.text:
at one time hope to his subjects that the
evil will not be for long, at another time

6893.text:
fear of the cruelty of the enemy, then preserving
himself adroitly from those subjects who seem

6899.text:
to him to be too bold.
Further, the enemy would naturally on his

6906.text:
arrival at once burn and ruin the country
at the time when the spirits of the people

6911.text:
are still hot and ready for the defence; and,
therefore, so much the less ought the prince

6917.text:
to hesitate; because after a time, when spirits
have cooled, the damage is already done, the

6924.text:
ills are incurred, and there is no longer
any remedy; and therefore they are so much

6930.text:
the more ready to unite with their prince,
he appearing to be under obligations to them

6935.text:
now that their houses have been burnt and
their possessions ruined in his defence. For

6941.text:
it is the nature of men to be bound by the
benefits they confer as much as by those they

6947.text:
receive. Therefore, if everything is well
considered, it will not be difficult for a

6953.text:
wise prince to keep the minds of his citizens
steadfast from first to last, when he does

6960.text:
not fail to support and defend them.
End of Chapter X

6966.text:
CHAPTER XI — CONCERNING ECCLESIASTICAL PRINCIPALITIES
It only remains now to speak of ecclesiastical

6974.text:
principalities, touching which all difficulties
are prior to getting possession, because they

6979.text:
are acquired either by capacity or good fortune,
and they can be held without either; for they

6986.text:
are sustained by the ancient ordinances of
religion, which are so all-powerful, and of

6992.text:
such a character that the principalities may
be held no matter how their princes behave

6998.text:
and live. These princes alone have states
and do not defend them; and they have subjects

7005.text:
and do not rule them; and the states, although
unguarded, are not taken from them, and the

7011.text:
subjects, although not ruled, do not care,
and they have neither the desire nor the ability

7016.text:
to alienate themselves. Such principalities
only are secure and happy. But being upheld

7025.text:
by powers, to which the human mind cannot
reach, I shall speak no more of them, because,

7031.text:
being exalted and maintained by God, it would
be the act of a presumptuous and rash man

7037.text:
to discuss them.
Nevertheless, if any one should ask of me

7042.text:
how comes it that the Church has attained
such greatness in temporal power, seeing that

7048.text:
from Alexander backwards the Italian potentates
(not only those who have been called potentates,

7055.text:
but every baron and lord, though the smallest)
have valued the temporal power very slightly—yet

7062.text:
now a king of France trembles before it, and
it has been able to drive him from Italy,

7068.text:
and to ruin the Venetians—although this
may be very manifest, it does not appear to

7073.text:
me superfluous to recall it in some measure
to memory.

7079.text:
Before Charles, King of France, passed into
Italy, [Footnote: Charles VIII invaded Italy

7086.text:
in 1494.] Before Charles, King of France,
passed into Italy, this country was under

7094.text:
the dominion of the Pope, the Venetians, the
King of Naples, the Duke of Milan, and the

7100.text:
Florentines. These potentates had two principal
anxieties: the one, that no foreigner should

7107.text:
enter Italy under arms; the other, that none
of themselves should seize more territory.

7114.text:
Those about whom there was the most anxiety
were the Pope and the Venetians. To restrain

7120.text:
the Venetians the union of all the others
was necessary, as it was for the defence of

7126.text:
Ferrara; and to keep down the Pope they made
use of the barons of Rome, who, being divided

7133.text:
into two factions, Orsini and Colonnesi, had
always a pretext for disorder, and, standing

7140.text:
with arms in their hands under the eyes of
the Pontiff, kept the pontificate weak and

7146.text:
powerless. And although there might arise
sometimes a courageous pope, such as Sixtus,

7153.text:
yet neither fortune nor wisdom could rid him
of these annoyances. And the short life of

7159.text:
a pope is also a cause of weakness; for in
the ten years, which is the average life of

7164.text:
a pope, he can with difficulty lower one of
the factions; and if, so to speak, one people

7171.text:
should almost destroy the Colonnesi, another
would arise hostile to the Orsini, who would

7177.text:
support their opponents, and yet would not
have time to ruin the Orsini. This was the

7183.text:
reason why the temporal powers of the pope
were little esteemed in Italy.

7189.text:
Alexander the Sixth arose afterwards, who
of all the pontiffs that have ever been showed

7195.text:
how a pope with both money and arms was able
to prevail; and through the instrumentality

7201.text:
of the Duke Valentino, and by reason of the
entry of the French, he brought about all

7206.text:
those things which I have discussed above
in the actions of the duke. And although his

7212.text:
intention was not to aggrandize the Church,
but the duke, nevertheless, what he did contributed

7219.text:
to the greatness of the Church, which, after
his death and the ruin of the duke, became

7225.text:
the heir to all his labours.
Pope Julius came afterwards and found the

7231.text:
Church strong, possessing all the Romagna,
the barons of Rome reduced to impotence, and,

7237.text:
through the chastisements of Alexander, the
factions wiped out; he also found the way

7243.text:
open to accumulate money in a manner such
as had never been practised before Alexander's

7249.text:
time. Such things Julius not only followed,
but improved upon, and he intended to gain

7256.text:
Bologna, to ruin the Venetians, and to drive
the French out of Italy. All of these enterprises

7263.text:
prospered with him, and so much the more to
his credit, inasmuch as he did everything

7268.text:
to strengthen the Church and not any private
person. He kept also the Orsini and Colonnesi

7276.text:
factions within the bounds in which he found
them; and although there was among them some

7281.text:
mind to make disturbance, nevertheless he
held two things firm: the one, the greatness

7287.text:
of the Church, with which he terrified them;
and the other, not allowing them to have their

7293.text:
own cardinals, who caused the disorders among
them. For whenever these factions have their

7299.text:
cardinals they do not remain quiet for long,
because cardinals foster the factions in Rome

7306.text:
and out of it, and the barons are compelled
to support them, and thus from the ambitions

7311.text:
of prelates arise disorders and tumults among
the barons. For these reasons his Holiness

7318.text:
Pope Leo [Footnote: Pope Leo X was the Cardinal
de' Medici.] For these reasons his Holiness

7326.text:
Pope Leo found the pontificate most powerful,
and it is to be hoped that, if others made

7333.text:
it great in arms, he will make it still greater
and more venerated by his goodness and infinite

7340.text:
other virtues.
End of Chapter XI

7349.text:
CHAPTER XII — HOW MANY KINDS OF SOLDIERY
THERE ARE, AND CONCERNING MERCENARIES

7356.text:
Having discoursed particularly on the characteristics
of such principalities as in the beginning

7362.text:
I proposed to discuss, and having considered
in some degree the causes of their being good

7368.text:
or bad, and having shown the methods by which
many have sought to acquire them and to hold

7374.text:
them, it now remains for me to discuss generally
the means of offence and defence which belong

7380.text:
to each of them.
We have seen above how necessary it is for

7384.text:
a prince to have his foundations well laid,
otherwise it follows of necessity he will

7390.text:
go to ruin. The chief foundations of all states,
new as well as old or composite, are good

7398.text:
laws and good arms; and as there cannot be
good laws where the state is not well armed,

7404.text:
it follows that where they are well armed
they have good laws. I shall leave the laws

7410.text:
out of the discussion and shall speak of the
arms.

7415.text:
I say, therefore, that the arms with which
a prince defends his state are either his

7420.text:
own, or they are mercenaries, auxiliaries,
or mixed. Mercenaries and auxiliaries are

7428.text:
useless and dangerous; and if one holds his
state based on these arms, he will stand neither

7434.text:
firm nor safe; for they are disunited, ambitious,
and without discipline, unfaithful, valiant

7442.text:
before friends, cowardly before enemies; they
have neither the fear of God nor fidelity

7448.text:
to men, and destruction is deferred only so
long as the attack is; for in peace one is

7454.text:
robbed by them, and in war by the enemy. The
fact is, they have no other attraction or

7461.text:
reason for keeping the field than a trifle
of stipend, which is not sufficient to make

7467.text:
them willing to die for you. They are ready
enough to be your soldiers whilst you do not

7473.text:
make war, but if war comes they take themselves
off or run from the foe; which I should have

7479.text:
little trouble to prove, for the ruin of Italy
has been caused by nothing else than by resting

7484.text:
all her hopes for many years on mercenaries,
and although they formerly made some display

7491.text:
and appeared valiant amongst themselves, yet
when the foreigners came they showed what

7497.text:
they were. Thus it was that Charles, King
of France, was allowed to seize Italy with

7503.text:
chalk in hand; [Footnote: "With chalk in hand,"
"col gesso." This is one of the bons mots

7511.text:
of Alexander VI, and refers to the ease with
which Charles VIII seized Italy, implying

7517.text:
that it was only necessary for him to send
his quartermasters to chalk up the billets

7522.text:
for his soldiers to conquer the country. Compare
"The History of Henry VII," by Lord Bacon:

7530.text:
"King Charles had conquered the realm of Naples,
and lost it again, in a kind of a felicity

7536.text:
of a dream. He passed the whole length of
Italy without resistance: so that it was true

7542.text:
what Pope Alexander was wont to say: That
the Frenchmen came into Italy with chalk in

7548.text:
their hands, to mark up their lodgings, rather
than with swords to fight."

7553.text:
Thus it was that Charles, King of France,
was allowed to seize Italy with chalk in hand;

7561.text:
and he who told us that our sins were the
cause of it told the truth, but they were

7566.text:
not the sins he imagined, but those which
I have related. And as they were the sins

7571.text:
of princes, it is the princes who have also
suffered the penalty.

7577.text:
I wish to demonstrate further the infelicity
of these arms. The mercenary captains are

7583.text:
either capable men or they are not; if they
are, you cannot trust them, because they always

7589.text:
aspire to their own greatness, either by oppressing
you, who are their master, or others contrary

7596.text:
to your intentions; but if the captain is
not skilful, you are ruined in the usual way.

7603.text:
And if it be urged that whoever is armed will
act in the same way, whether mercenary or

7608.text:
not, I reply that when arms have to be resorted
to, either by a prince or a republic, then

7616.text:
the prince ought to go in person and perform
the duty of a captain; the republic has to

7622.text:
send its citizens, and when one is sent who
does not turn out satisfactorily, it ought

7627.text:
to recall him, and when one is worthy, to
hold him by the laws so that he does not leave

7634.text:
the command. And experience has shown princes
and republics, single-handed, making the greatest

7642.text:
progress, and mercenaries doing nothing except
damage; and it is more difficult to bring

7648.text:
a republic, armed with its own arms, under
the sway of one of its citizens than it is

7653.text:
to bring one armed with foreign arms. Rome
and Sparta stood for many ages armed and free.

7660.text:
The Switzers are completely armed and quite
free.

7665.text:
Of ancient mercenaries, for example, there
are the Carthaginians, who were oppressed

7671.text:
by their mercenary soldiers after the first
war with the Romans, although the Carthaginians

7677.text:
had their own citizens for captains. After
the death of Epaminondas, Philip of Macedon

7684.text:
was made captain of their soldiers by the
Thebans, and after victory he took away their

7690.text:
liberty.
Duke Filippo being dead, the Milanese enlisted

7694.text:
Francesco Sforza against the Venetians, and
he, having overcome the enemy at Caravaggio,

7701.text:
allied himself with them to crush the Milanese,
his masters. [Footnote: Battle of Caravaggio,

7710.text:
15th September 1448.] His father, Sforza,
having been engaged by Queen Johanna [Footnote:

7719.text:
Johanna II of Naples, the widow of Ladislao,
King of Naples.] His father, Sforza, having

7729.text:
been engaged by Queen Johanna of Naples, left
her unprotected, so that she was forced to

7736.text:
throw herself into the arms of the King of
Aragon, in order to save her kingdom. And

7742.text:
if the Venetians and Florentines formerly
extended their dominions by these arms, and

7748.text:
yet their captains did not make themselves
princes, but have defended them, I reply that

7753.text:
the Florentines in this case have been favoured
by chance, for of the able captains, of whom

7760.text:
they might have stood in fear, some have not
conquered, some have been opposed, and others

7766.text:
have turned their ambitions elsewhere. One
who did not conquer was Giovanni Acuto, [Footnote:

7774.text:
Giovanni Acuto. An English knight whose name
was Sir John Hawkwood. He fought in the English

7781.text:
wars in France, and was knighted by Edward
III; afterwards he collected a body of troops

7787.text:
and went into Italy. These became the famous
"White Company." He took part in many wars,

7794.text:
and died in Florence in 1394. He was born
about 1320 at Sible Hedingham, a village in

7802.text:
Essex. He married Domnia, a daughter of Bernabo
Visconti.] One who did not conquer was Giovanni

7810.text:
Acuto,and since he did not conquer his fidelity
cannot be proved; but every one will acknowledge

7818.text:
that, had he conquered, the Florentines would
have stood at his discretion. Sforza had the

7824.text:
Bracceschi always against him, so they watched
each other. Francesco turned his ambition

7831.text:
to Lombardy; Braccio against the Church and
the kingdom of Naples. But let us come to

7837.text:
that which happened a short while ago. The
Florentines appointed as their captain Pagolo

7843.text:
Vitelli, a most prudent man, who from a private
position had risen to the greatest renown.

7850.text:
If this man had taken Pisa, nobody can deny
that it would have been proper for the Florentines

7857.text:
to keep in with him, for if he became the
soldier of their enemies they had no means

7862.text:
of resisting, and if they held to him they
must obey him. The Venetians, if their achievements

7868.text:
are considered, will be seen to have acted
safely and gloriously so long as they sent

7874.text:
to war their own men, when with armed gentlemen
and plebians they did valiantly. This was

7880.text:
before they turned to enterprises on land,
but when they began to fight on land they

7886.text:
forsook this virtue and followed the custom
of Italy. And in the beginning of their expansion

7893.text:
on land, through not having much territory,
and because of their great reputation, they

7899.text:
had not much to fear from their captains;
but when they expanded, as under Carmignuola,

7907.text:
[Footnote: Carmignuola. Francesco Bussone,
born at Carmagnola about 1390, executed at

7914.text:
Venice, 5th May 1432.] but when they expanded,
as under Carmignuola, they had a taste of

7923.text:
this mistake; for, having found him a most
valiant man (they beat the Duke of Milan under

7929.text:
his leadership), and, on the other hand, knowing
how lukewarm he was in the war, they feared

7935.text:
they would no longer conquer under him, and
for this reason they were not willing, nor

7940.text:
were they able, to let him go; and so, not
to lose again that which they had acquired,

7946.text:
they were compelled, in order to secure themselves,
to murder him. They had afterwards for their

7952.text:
captains Bartolomeo da Bergamo, Roberto da
San Severino, the count of Pitigliano, [Footnote:

7963.text:
Bartolomeo Colleoni of Bergamo; died 1457.
Roberto of San Severino; died fighting for

7972.text:
Venice against Sigismund, Duke of Austria,
in 1487. "Primo capitano in Italia."— Machiavelli.

7982.text:
Count of Pitigliano; Nicolo Orsini, born 1442,
died 1510.] the count of Pitigliano, and the

7992.text:
like, under whom they had to dread loss and
not gain, as happened afterwards at Vaila,

7999.text:
[Footnote: Battle of Vaila in 1509.] where
in one battle they lost that which in eight

8007.text:
hundred years they had acquired with so much
trouble. Because from such arms conquests

8013.text:
come but slowly, long delayed and inconsiderable,
but the losses sudden and portentous.

8022.text:
And as with these examples I have reached
Italy, which has been ruled for many years

8027.text:
by mercenaries, I wish to discuss them more
seriously, in order that, having seen their

8033.text:
rise and progress, one may be better prepared
to counteract them. You must understand that

8040.text:
the empire has recently come to be repudiated
in Italy, that the Pope has acquired more

8046.text:
temporal power, and that Italy has been divided
up into more states, for the reason that many

8052.text:
of the great cities took up arms against their
nobles, who, formerly favoured by the emperor,

8059.text:
were oppressing them, whilst the Church was
favouring them so as to gain authority in

8065.text:
temporal power: in many others their citizens
became princes. From this it came to pass

8072.text:
that Italy fell partly into the hands of the
Church and of republics, and, the Church consisting

8078.text:
of priests and the republic of citizens unaccustomed
to arms, both commenced to enlist foreigners.

8086.text:
The first who gave renown to this soldiery
was Alberigo da Conio, the Romagnian [Footnote:

8095.text:
Alberigo da Conio. Alberico da Barbiano, Count
of Cunio in Romagna. He was the leader of

8103.text:
the famous "Company of St George," composed
entirely of Italian soldiers. He died in 1409.]

8113.text:
From the school of this man sprang, among
others, Braccio and Sforza, who in their time

8119.text:
were the arbiters of Italy. After these came
all the other captains who till now have directed

8126.text:
the arms of Italy; and the end of all their
valour has been, that she has been overrun

8131.text:
by Charles, robbed by Louis, ravaged by Ferdinand,
and insulted by the Switzers. The principle

8139.text:
that has guided them has been, first, to lower
the credit of infantry so that they might

8145.text:
increase their own. They did this because,
subsisting on their pay and without territory,

8152.text:
they were unable to support many soldiers,
and a few infantry did not give them any authority;

8158.text:
so they were led to employ cavalry, with a
moderate force of which they were maintained

8164.text:
and honoured; and affairs were brought to
such a pass that, in an army of twenty thousand

8170.text:
soldiers, there were not to be found two thousand
foot soldiers. They had, besides this, used

8177.text:
every art to lessen fatigue and danger to
themselves and their soldiers, not killing

8183.text:
in the fray, but taking prisoners and liberating
without ransom. They did not attack towns

8190.text:
at night, nor did the garrisons of the towns
attack encampments at night; they did not

8196.text:
surround the camp either with stockade or
ditch, nor did they campaign in the winter.

8202.text:
All these things were permitted by their military
rules, and devised by them to avoid, as I

8209.text:
have said, both fatigue and dangers; thus
they have brought Italy to slavery and contempt.

8217.text:
End of Chapter XII
CHAPTER XIII — CONCERNING AUXILIARIES, MIXED

8223.text:
SOLDIERY, AND ONE'S OWN
Auxiliaries, which are the other useless arm,

8229.text:
are employed when a prince is called in with
his forces to aid and defend, as was done

8235.text:
by Pope Julius in the most recent times; for
he, having, in the enterprise against Ferrara,

8242.text:
had poor proof of his mercenaries, turned
to auxiliaries, and stipulated with Ferdinand,

8248.text:
King of Spain, for his assistance with men
and arms. These arms may be useful and good

8269.text:
in themselves, but for him who calls them
in they are always disadvantageous; for losing,

8277.text:
one is undone, and winning, one is their captive.
And although ancient histories may be full

8283.text:
of examples, I do not wish to leave this recent
one of Pope Julius the Second, the peril of

8290.text:
which cannot fail to be perceived; for he,
wishing to get Ferrara, threw himself entirely

8297.text:
into the hands of the foreigner. But his good
fortune brought about a third event, so that

8303.text:
he did not reap the fruit of his rash choice;
because, having his auxiliaries routed at

8309.text:
Ravenna, and the Switzers having risen and
driven out the conquerors (against all expectation,

8316.text:
both his and others), it so came to pass that
he did not become prisoner to his enemies,

8322.text:
they having fled, nor to his auxiliaries,
he having conquered by other arms than theirs.

8330.text:
The Florentines, being entirely without arms,
sent ten thousand Frenchmen to take Pisa,

8337.text:
whereby they ran more danger than at any other
time of their troubles.

8342.text:
The Emperor of Constantinople, [Footnote:
Joannes Cantacuzenus, born 1300, died 1383.]

8353.text:
The Emperor of Constantinople, to oppose his
neighbours, sent ten thousand Turks into Greece,

8360.text:
who, on the war being finished, were not willing
to quit; this was the beginning of the servitude

8369.text:
Therefore, let him who has no desire to conquer
make use of these arms, for they are much

8375.text:
more hazardous than mercenaries, because with
them the ruin is ready made; they are all

8381.text:
united, all yield obedience to others; but
with mercenaries, when they have conquered,

8387.text:
more time and better opportunities are needed
to injure you; they are not all of one community,

8393.text:
they are found and paid by you, and a third
party, which you have made their head, is

8398.text:
not able all at once to assume enough authority
to injure you. In conclusion, in mercenaries

8405.text:
dastardy is most dangerous; in auxiliaries,
valour. The wise prince, therefore, has always

8413.text:
avoided these arms and turned to his own;
and has been willing rather to lose with them

8419.text:
than to conquer with the others, not deeming
that a real victory which is gained with the

8425.text:
arms of others.
I shall never hesitate to cite Cesare Borgia

8431.text:
and his actions. This duke entered the Romagna
with auxiliaries, taking there only French

8437.text:
soldiers, and with them he captured Imola
and Forli; but afterwards, such forces not

8444.text:
appearing to him reliable, he turned to mercenaries,
discerning less danger in them, and enlisted

8451.text:
the Orsini and Vitelli; whom presently, on
handling and finding them doubtful, unfaithful,

8459.text:
and dangerous, he destroyed and turned to
his own men. And the difference between one

8465.text:
and the other of these forces can easily be
seen when one considers the difference there

8471.text:
was in the reputation of the duke, when he
had the French, when he had the Orsini and

8476.text:
Vitelli, and when he relied on his own soldiers,
on whose fidelity he could always count and

8483.text:
found it ever increasing; he was never esteemed
more highly than when every one saw that he

8490.text:
was complete master of his own forces.
I was not intending to go beyond Italian and

8497.text:
recent examples, but I am unwilling to leave
out Hiero, the Syracusan, he being one of

8504.text:
those I have named above. This man, as I have
said, made head of the army by the Syracusans,

8511.text:
soon found out that a mercenary soldiery,
constituted like our Italian condottieri,

8518.text:
was of no use; and it appearing to him that
he could neither keep them not let them go,

8524.text:
he had them all cut to pieces, and afterwards
made war with his own forces and not with

8530.text:
aliens.
I wish also to recall to memory an instance

8535.text:
from the Old Testament applicable to this
subject. David offered himself to Saul to

8541.text:
fight with Goliath, the Philistine champion,
and, to give him courage, Saul armed him with

8548.text:
his own weapons; which David rejected as soon
as he had them on his back, saying he could

8553.text:
make no use of them, and that he wished to
meet the enemy with his sling and his knife.

8560.text:
In conclusion, the arms of others either fall
from your back, or they weigh you down, or

8566.text:
they bind you fast.
Charles the Seventh, the father of King Louis

8571.text:
the Eleventh, [Footnotes: Charles VII of France,
surnamed "The Victorious," born 1403, died

8581.text:
1461. Louis the Eleventh; Louis XI, son of
the above, born 1423, died 1483.] Charles

8591.text:
the Seventh, the father of King Louis the
Eleventh, having by good fortune and valour

8597.text:
liberated France from the English, recognized
the necessity of being armed with forces of

8603.text:
his own, and he established in his kingdom
ordinances concerning men-at-arms and infantry.

8610.text:
Afterwards his son, King Louis, abolished
the infantry and began to enlist the Switzers,

8617.text:
which mistake, followed by others, is, as
is now seen, a source of peril to that kingdom;

8624.text:
because, having raised the reputation of the
Switzers, he has entirely diminished the value

8630.text:
of his own arms, for he has destroyed the
infantry altogether; and his men-at-arms he

8636.text:
has subordinated to others, for, being as
they are so accustomed to fight along with

8642.text:
Switzers, it does not appear that they can
now conquer without them. Hence it arises

8649.text:
that the French cannot stand against the Switzers,
and without the Switzers they do not come

8654.text:
off well against others. The armies of the
French have thus become mixed, partly mercenary

8661.text:
and partly national, both of which arms together
are much better than mercenaries alone or

8667.text:
auxiliaries alone, but much inferior to one's
own forces. And this example proves it, for

8674.text:
the kingdom of France would be unconquerable
if the ordinance of Charles had been enlarged

8682.text:
But the scanty wisdom of man, on entering
into an affair which looks well at first,

8688.text:
cannot discern the poison that is hidden in
it, as I have said above of hectic fevers.

8695.text:
Therefore, if he who rules a principality
cannot recognize evils until they are upon

8703.text:
him, he is not truly wise; and this insight
is given to few. And if the first disaster

8710.text:
to the Roman Empire [Footnote: "Many speakers
to the House the other night in the debate

8717.text:
on the reduction of armaments seemed to show
a most lamentable ignorance of the conditions

8723.text:
under which the British Empire maintains its
existence. When Mr Balfour replied to the

8728.text:
allegations that the Roman Empire sank under
the weight of its military obligations, he

8735.text:
said that this was 'wholly unhistorical.'
He might well have added that the Roman power

8740.text:
was at its zenith when every citizen acknowledged
his liability to fight for the State, but

8747.text:
that it began to decline as soon as this obligation
was no longer recognized."—Pall Mall Gazette,

8754.text:
15th May 1906.] And if the first disaster
to the Roman Empire should be examined, it

8763.text:
will be found to have commenced only with
the enlisting of the Goths; because from that

8768.text:
time the vigour of the Roman Empire began
to decline, and all that valour which had

8774.text: raised it passed away to others.

8776.text:
I conclude, therefore, that no principality
is secure without having its own forces; on

8784.text:
the contrary, it is entirely dependent on
good fortune, not having the valour which

8790.text:
in adversity would defend it. And it has always
been the opinion and judgment of wise men

8797.text:
that nothing can be so uncertain or unstable
as fame or power not founded on its own strength.

8805.text:
And one's own forces are those which are composed
either of subjects, citizens, or dependents;

8811.text:
all others are mercenaries or auxiliaries.
And the way to make ready one's own forces

8818.text:
will be easily found if the rules suggested
by me shall be reflected upon, and if one

8824.text:
will consider how Philip, the father of Alexander
the Great, and many republics and princes

8830.text:
have armed and organized themselves, to which
rules I entirely commit myself.

8839.text:
End of Chapter XIII
CHAPTER XIV — THAT WHICH CONCERNS A PRINCE

8846.text:
ON THE SUBJECT OF THE ART OF WAR
A prince ought to have no other aim or thought,

8853.text:
nor select anything else for his study, than
war and its rules and discipline; for this

8860.text:
is the sole art that belongs to him who rules,
and it is of such force that it not only upholds

8867.text:
those who are born princes, but it often enables
men to rise from a private station to that

8872.text:
rank. And, on the contrary, it is seen that
when princes have thought more of ease than

8879.text:
of arms they have lost their states. And the
first cause of your losing it is to neglect

8885.text:
this art; and what enables you to acquire
a state is to be master of the art. Francesco

8893.text:
Sforza, through being martial, from a private
person became Duke of Milan; and the sons,

8900.text:
through avoiding the hardships and troubles
of arms, from dukes became private persons.

8906.text:
For among other evils which being unarmed
brings you, it causes you to be despised,

8912.text:
and this is one of those ignominies against
which a prince ought to guard himself, as

8917.text:
is shown later on. Because there is nothing
proportionate between the armed and the unarmed;

8924.text:
and it is not reasonable that he who is armed
should yield obedience willingly to him who

8929.text:
is unarmed, or that the unarmed man should
be secure among armed servants. Because, there

8937.text:
being in the one disdain and in the other
suspicion, it is not possible for them to

8942.text:
work well together. And therefore a prince
who does not understand the art of war, over

8948.text:
and above the other misfortunes already mentioned,
cannot be respected by his soldiers, nor can

8954.text:
he rely on them. He ought never, therefore,
to have out of his thoughts this subject of

8960.text:
war, and in peace he should addict himself
more to its exercise than in war; this he

8966.text:
can do in two ways, the one by action, the
other by study.

8972.text:
As regards action, he ought above all things
to keep his men well organized and drilled,

8978.text:
to follow incessantly the chase, by which
he accustoms his body to hardships, and learns

8984.text:
something of the nature of localities, and
gets to find out how the mountains rise, how

8990.text:
the valleys open out, how the plains lie,
and to understand the nature of rivers and

8996.text:
marshes, and in all this to take the greatest
care. Which knowledge is useful in two ways.

9004.text:
Firstly, he learns to know his country, and
is better able to undertake its defence; afterwards,

9011.text:
by means of the knowledge and observation
of that locality, he understands with ease

9016.text:
any other which it may be necessary for him
to study hereafter; because the hills, valleys,

9022.text:
and plains, and rivers and marshes that are,
for instance, in Tuscany, have a certain resemblance

9029.text:
to those of other countries, so that with
a knowledge of the aspect of one country one

9034.text:
can easily arrive at a knowledge of others.
And the prince that lacks this skill lacks

9040.text:
the essential which it is desirable that a
captain should possess, for it teaches him

9046.text:
to surprise his enemy, to select quarters,
to lead armies, to array the battle, to besiege

9061.text:
last of the Greeks," born 252 B.C., died 183
B.C.] Philopoemen, Prince of the Achaeans,

9072.text:
among other praises which writers have bestowed
on him, is commended because in time of peace

9078.text:
he never had anything in his mind but the
rules of war; and when he was in the country

9083.text:
with friends, he often stopped and reasoned
with them: "If the enemy should be upon that

9089.text:
hill, and we should find ourselves here with
our army, with whom would be the advantage?

9095.text:
How should one best advance to meet him, keeping
the ranks? If we should wish to retreat, how

9101.text:
ought we to pursue?" And he would set forth
to them, as he went, all the chances that

9107.text:
could befall an army; he would listen to their
opinion and state his, confirming it with

9112.text:
reasons, so that by these continual discussions
there could never arise, in time of war, any

9119.text:
unexpected circumstances that he could not
deal with.

9124.text:
But to exercise the intellect the prince should
read histories, and study there the actions

9130.text:
of illustrious men, to see how they have borne
themselves in war, to examine the causes of

9136.text:
their victories and defeat, so as to avoid
the latter and imitate the former; and above

9142.text:
all do as an illustrious man did, who took
as an exemplar one who had been praised and

9148.text:
famous before him, and whose achievements
and deeds he always kept in his mind, as it

9154.text:
is said Alexander the Great imitated Achilles,
Caesar Alexander, Scipio Cyrus. And whoever

9162.text:
reads the life of Cyrus, written by Xenophon,
will recognize afterwards in the life of Scipio

9169.text:
how that imitation was his glory, and how
in chastity, affability, humanity, and liberality

9176.text:
Scipio conformed to those things which have
been written of Cyrus by Xenophon. A wise

9183.text:
prince ought to observe some such rules, and
never in peaceful times stand idle, but increase

9190.text:
his resources with industry in such a way
that they may be available to him in adversity,

9197.text:
so that if fortune chances it may find him
prepared to resist her blows.

9202.text:
End of Chapter XIV
CHAPTER XV — CONCERNING THINGS FOR WHICH

9208.text:
MEN, AND ESPECIALLY PRINCES, ARE PRAISED OR
BLAMED

9214.text:
It remains now to see what ought to be the
rules of conduct for a prince towards subject

9220.text:
and friends. And as I know that many have
written on this point, I expect I shall be

9225.text:
considered presumptuous in mentioning it again,
especially as in discussing it I shall depart

9231.text:
from the methods of other people. But, it
being my intention to write a thing which

9237.text:
shall be useful to him who apprehends it,
it appears to me more appropriate to follow

9243.text:
up the real truth of the matter than the imagination
of it; for many have pictured republics and

9249.text:
principalities which in fact have never been
known or seen, because how one lives is so

9255.text:
far distant from how one ought to live, that
he who neglects what is done for what ought

9261.text:
to be done, sooner effects his ruin than his
preservation; for a man who wishes to act

9267.text:
entirely up to his professions of virtue soon
meets with what destroys him among so much

9274.text:
that is evil.
Hence it is necessary for a prince wishing

9279.text:
to hold his own to know how to do wrong, and
to make use of it or not according to necessity.

9285.text:
Therefore, putting on one side imaginary things
concerning a prince, and discussing those

9292.text:
which are real, I say that all men when they
are spoken of, and chiefly princes for being

9298.text:
more highly placed, are remarkable for some
of those qualities which bring them either

9303.text:
blame or praise; and thus it is that one is
reputed liberal, another miserly, using a

9310.text:
Tuscan term (because an avaricious person
in our language is still he who desires to

9316.text:
possess by robbery, whilst we call one miserly
who deprives himself too much of the use of

9322.text:
his own); one is reputed generous, one rapacious;
one cruel, one compassionate; one faithless,

9331.text:
another faithful; one effeminate and cowardly,
another bold and brave; one affable, another

9338.text:
haughty; one lascivious, another chaste; one
sincere, another cunning; one hard, another

9347.text:
easy; one grave, another frivolous; one religious,
another unbelieving, and the like. And I know

9356.text:
that every one will confess that it would
be most praiseworthy in a prince to exhibit

9361.text:
all the above qualities that are considered
good; but because they can neither be entirely

9367.text:
possessed nor observed, for human conditions
do not permit it, it is necessary for him

9373.text:
to be sufficiently prudent that he may know
how to avoid the reproach of those vices which

9379.text:
would lose him his state; and also to keep
himself, if it be possible, from those which

9386.text:
would not lose him it; but this not being
possible, he may with less hesitation abandon

9393.text:
himself to them. And again, he need not make
himself uneasy at incurring a reproach for

9399.text:
those vices without which the state can only
be saved with difficulty, for if everything

9405.text:
is considered carefully, it will be found
that something which looks like virtue, if

9410.text:
followed, would be his ruin; whilst something
else, which looks like vice, yet followed

9416.text:
brings him security and prosperity.
End of Chapter XV

9422.text:
CHAPTER XVI — CONCERNING LIBERALITY AND
MEANNESS

9427.text:
Commencing then with the first of the above-named
characteristics, I say that it would be well

9432.text:
to be reputed liberal. Nevertheless, liberality
exercised in a way that does not bring you

9438.text:
the reputation for it, injures you; for if
one exercises it honestly and as it should

9445.text:
be exercised, it may not become known, and
you will not avoid the reproach of its opposite.

9451.text:
Therefore, any one wishing to maintain among
men the name of liberal is obliged to avoid

9458.text:
no attribute of magnificence; so that a prince
thus inclined will consume in such acts all

9465.text:
his property, and will be compelled in the
end, if he wish to maintain the name of liberal,

9471.text:
to unduly weigh down his people, and tax them,
and do everything he can to get money. This

9478.text:
will soon make him odious to his subjects,
and becoming poor he will be little valued

9483.text:
by any one; thus, with his liberality, having
offended many and rewarded few, he is affected

9491.text:
by the very first trouble and imperilled by
whatever may be the first danger; recognizing

9497.text:
this himself, and wishing to draw back from
it, he runs at once into the reproach of being

9503.text:
miserly.
Therefore, a prince, not being able to exercise

9508.text:
this virtue of liberality in such a way that
it is recognized, except to his cost, if he

9514.text:
is wise he ought not to fear the reputation
of being mean, for in time he will come to

9520.text:
be more considered than if liberal, seeing
that with his economy his revenues are enough,

9527.text:
that he can defend himself against all attacks,
and is able to engage in enterprises without

9533.text:
burdening his people; thus it comes to pass
that he exercises liberality towards all from

9540.text:
whom he does not take, who are numberless,
and meanness towards those to whom he does

9545.text:
not give, who are few.
We have not seen great things done in our

9551.text:
time except by those who have been considered
mean; the rest have failed. Pope Julius the

9557.text:
Second was assisted in reaching the papacy
by a reputation for liberality, yet he did

9563.text:
not strive afterwards to keep it up, when
he made war on the King of France; and he

9569.text:
made many wars without imposing any extraordinary
tax on his subjects, for he supplied his additional

9577.text:
expenses out of his long thriftiness. The
present King of Spain would not have undertaken

9584.text:
or conquered in so many enterprises if he
had been reputed liberal. A prince, therefore,

9591.text:
provided that he has not to rob his subjects,
that he can defend himself, that he does not

9596.text:
become poor and abject, that he is not forced
to become rapacious, ought to hold of little

9603.text:
account a reputation for being mean, for it
is one of those vices which will enable him

9608.text:
to govern.
And if any one should say: Caesar obtained

9613.text:
empire by liberality, and many others have
reached the highest positions by having been

9619.text:
liberal, and by being considered so, I answer:
Either you are a prince in fact, or in a way

9626.text:
to become one. In the first case this liberality
is dangerous, in the second it is very necessary

9634.text:
to be considered liberal; and Caesar was one
of those who wished to become pre-eminent

9639.text:
in Rome; but if he had survived after becoming
so, and had not moderated his expenses, he

9646.text:
would have destroyed his government. And if
any one should reply: Many have been princes,

9653.text:
and have done great things with armies, who
have been considered very liberal, I reply:

9659.text:
Either a prince spends that which is his own
or his subjects' or else that of others. In

9665.text:
the first case he ought to be sparing, in
the second he ought not to neglect any opportunity

9671.text:
for liberality. And to the prince who goes
forth with his army, supporting it by pillage,

9677.text:
sack, and extortion, handling that which belongs
to others, this liberality is necessary, otherwise

9685.text:
he would not be followed by soldiers. And
of that which is neither yours nor your subjects'

9691.text:
you can be a ready giver, as were Cyrus, Caesar,
and Alexander; because it does not take away

9697.text:
your reputation if you squander that of others,
but adds to it; it is only squandering your

9704.text:
own that injures you.
And there is nothing wastes so rapidly as

9709.text:
liberality, for even whilst you exercise it
you lose the power to do so, and so become

9716.text:
either poor or despised, or else, in avoiding
poverty, rapacious and hated. And a prince

9724.text:
should guard himself, above all things, against
being despised and hated; and liberality leads

9732.text:
you to both. Therefore it is wiser to have
a reputation for meanness which brings reproach

9738.text:
without hatred, than to be compelled through
seeking a reputation for liberality to incur

9745.text:
a name for rapacity which begets reproach
with hatred.
